Any child between the ages of 12 and 16 years, who is not officially excused from school attendance by a parent or guardian and who fails to attend his designated school as required by law during regular school hours, has committed a violation. Prior to being charged with a violation under this section, the police department shall provide a written warning/notice to the child and to the parent or guardian of said child. 
(c)  Parents/guardians. Any parent or guardian who knowingly fails to have his child between the ages of 12 and 16 years attend his designated school as required by law during regular school hours has committed a violation. This section shall not apply to any parent or guardian who has officially excused his child due to illness or other legitimate reason. Prior to being charged with a violation under this section, the police department shall provide a written warning/notice to said parent or guardian. 
(d)  Penalties. Any person found violating any provisions of this section shall, upon conviction by a court of jurisdiction, be subject to the following penalties: 
(1)  First offense. Pay a fine no greater than $500.00, all of which shall be suspended except for $25.00 upon completion of 60 consecutive truancy-free days. 
(2)  Second offense. Pay a fine no greater than $1,000.00, all of which shall be suspended except for $100.00 upon completion of 60 consecutive truancy-free days. As used in this section, the term "second offense" means a second violation committed within the same school year. 
(3)  Subsequent offense. Pay a fine no greater than $1,000.00 and be sentenced to whatever action the court deems necessary. As used in this section, the term "subsequent offense" means three or more violations committed within the same school year. 
(e)  Enforcement. The police department is authorized to take appropriate enforcement action consistent with state law and shall deliver any truant to his designated school. A police officer who finds probable cause that any violation of this section has been committed may issue a summons to any person found in violation in lieu of arrest. 
(Prior Code,  17.4.1-17.4.5; Ord. No. 2000-06, 11-1-2000) 
State Law reference- School attendance, RSA 193. 
Sec. 20-5. - Loitering in public ways and buildings; riding skateboards. 
(a)  No person shall sit or stand and loiter in or about any street, sidewalk, municipal land, or building or any other public place in the town, except the owners or tenants thereof, after having been requested by any owner, tenant or custodian thereof or by any police officer to depart therefrom. This shall not apply to persons who have a legitimate purpose for sitting or standing in such public places; or persons who are attending an approved public function; or persons who have authorization to use public property from the town council, town administrator or other designated town official. 
(b)  No person shall block or cause to be blocked any public sidewalk, street, or other public way nor shall any group of persons assemble in such a manner as to impede or block the orderly progress of pedestrian or vehicle traffic within the town. 
(c)  No person shall sit, stand or loiter in or about any public park within the town when such person is requested by any police officer to depart therefrom. Persons under the age of 17 years may be required to be accompanied by a parent or guardian if deemed necessary by a police officer. 
(d)  No person shall sit, stand or loiter in or about any municipally-owned or municipally-maintained land, park, building or parking lot between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. unless authorized by the town council, town administrator or other designated town official to do so. This section does not supersede other more restrictive hours which may be posted by proper authority; or allow any person to loiter about any municipally-owned property or building when said property or building is closed or prohibits access by other means. 
(e)  No person shall sit, stand or loiter in or about the town police station, otherwise known as the John Andrew Gordon Memorial Building, so as to interfere with any emergency operations or essential functions of police personnel. Any person found to be disrupting or obstructing any police personnel engaged in official duties shall be in violation of this section. 
(f)  No person shall ride or use any skateboard on any sidewalk or within any municipally-owned land, park, building or parking lot within the town so as to interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic on such land, park, building or parking lot. No person shall ride or use any skateboard on any parking lot which is private property when such property is generally maintained for commercial and public use unless such person has the expressed approval from the owner or authorized person of such property to use the parking lot for skateboarding purposes. Any person who rides or uses any skateboard on any sidewalk or within any municipally-owned land, park, building or parking lot within the town shall yield a reasonable amount of space to any pedestrian or vehicular traffic and shall terminate skateboarding, if necessary, in order for pedestrian or vehicular traffic to pass. 
(g)  Any person found violating this section shall be guilty of a violation and may be fined up to $500.00 if an adult. A minor found violating any provision of this section may be processed in accordance with state juvenile laws. Any skateboard used in violation of subsection (f) of this section may be confiscated by the police department and held until returned to its lawful owner, or returned to a parent or guardian if the violation is committed by a minor. 
(Ord. No. 97-02,  1.0-7.0, 7-2-1997) 
Sec. 20-6. - Noise. 
(a)  Declaration. 
(1)  It is found and declared that the allowing, making or creation of loud, unnecessary, unreasonable or unusual noises within the limits of the town are a detriment to the public comfort, repose, health, peace, safety, convenience, welfare and prosperity of the residents of the town; and 
(2)  The necessity and public interest for the provisions and prohibitions hereinafter contained and enacted is a matter of legislative determination and public policy, and it is further declared that the provisions and prohibitions hereinafter contained and enacted are in pursuance of and for the purpose of comfort, repose, health, peace, safety, convenience, welfare and prosperity of the inhabitants within the town. 
(b)  Unlawful activities. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to make, create, cause, allow or continue to be made any loud, unnecessary, unreasonable or unusual noise or any noise which either annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace, safety, convenience, welfare or prosperity of any reasonable person within the town. 
(c)  Misuse of power. Loud, unnecessary, unreasonable and unusual noises shall include but not be limited to any noise caused by any one or more of the following actions of the operator of a motor vehicle operated within the limits of the town: 
(1)  Misuse of power exceeding tire traction limits in acceleration, sometimes referred to as "laying down rubber" or "peeling rubber." 
(2)  Misuse of braking power exceeding tire traction limits in deceleration where there is no emergency. 
(3)  Rapid acceleration by means of quick upshifting of transmission gears with either a clutch and manual transmission or automatic transmission. 
(4)  Rapid deceleration by means of quick downshifting of transmission gears with either a clutch and manual transmission or automatic transmission. 
(5)  Racing of an engine by manipulation of the accelerator, gas pedal, carburetor or gear selection whether the vehicle is in motion or stationary. 
(6)  The blowing of any horn except as a warning signal or other legitimate purpose whether the vehicle is in motion or stationary. 
(7)  The amplification of any vehicle radio, cassette player, CD player or similar music generating device in which pedestrian or vehicle traffic may be disturbed or distracted; or any amplification of any vehicle radio, cassette player, CD player or similar music generating device in which the driver or occupant to any vehicle may be disturbed or distracted from the obedience to emergency warning signals or other rules of the road as established by the state motor vehicle code. This shall include any factory installed or modified radio or accessory thereof, any portable radios or accessory thereof, any other type of music device or accessory thereof and any vehicle speaker or portable speaker generally utilized for listening to music sounds. 
(8)  Any noise generated by the unlawful modification of motor vehicle equipment; or any noise generated by the unlawful defect of motor vehicle equipment as defined by the state motor vehicle code. 
(d)  Loud parties or gatherings. Any person who is the owner, or a tenant, or a resident, or otherwise in control of any house, apartment, condominium unit, structure or other property located within the town, shall be responsible and liable for any loud, unnecessary, unreasonable or unusual noises made by, created by or caused by one or more persons gathered on said property which annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the public comfort, repose, health, peace, safety, convenience, welfare or prosperity of any reasonable person within the town. Further, any person who is the owner, tenant, resident or otherwise in control of any house, apartment, condominium unit, structure or other property located within the town is responsible for any loud, unnecessary, unreasonable or unusual noises if he allows any gathering of one or more persons to continue to make loud, unnecessary, unreasonable or unusual noises upon such property after having been advised of the disturbing affects such noise is having on any person within the town and the said noise then continues to disturb the public comfort, repose, health, peace, safety, convenience, welfare or prosperity of any person within the town. This subsection shall also apply to any person attending such party or gathering who violates any other provision of this section or who refuses to terminate the loud, unnecessary, unreasonable or unusual noise upon a request by a police officer to do so; or any person attending such party or gathering who refuses to disperse from a public place upon a request by a police officer to do so. 
(e)  Disturbance of peace. It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb the public comfort, repose, health, peace, safety, convenience, welfare or prosperity of any reasonable person within the town by making, creating, causing, allowing or continuing any loud, unnecessary, unreasonable or unusual noises. This shall include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  The operation of any electronic or battery-powered device such as a radio, television, musical instrument, phonograph, loudspeaker, or any other machine or device that may be used for the purpose of producing or reproducing sound-amplifying noises. 
(2)  Noises caused by yelling, screaming, shouting or hollering when there is no legitimate purpose for such noises. 
(f)  Operation of equipment or machinery. It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb the public comfort, repose, health, peace, safety, convenience, welfare or prosperity of any reasonable person within the town by making, creating, causing, allowing or continuing any loud, unnecessary, unreasonable or unusual noises by operating or causing the operation of equipment or machinery during certain time periods. 
(1)  Power tools. No person shall operate or cause the operation of any mechanically-powered saw, sander, grinder, drill, lawnmower or similar device, with the exception of snow-clearing equipment, between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. if such noise generated by the use of such equipment or machinery is likely to annoy, disturb, injure or endanger the comfort, repose, health, peace, safety, convenience, welfare or prosperity of any other person. 
(2)  Construction equipment. No person shall operate or cause the operation of any type of construction vehicle and leave it running and stationary within the town between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. if such noise generated by the use of such equipment is likely to annoy, disturb, injure or endanger the comfort, repose, health, peace, safety, convenience, welfare or prosperity of any person. This subsection shall also apply to construction activities such as hammering, earth-moving and the moving of construction vehicles at project sites during said time periods. 
(3)  Loading and unloading. No person shall load or unload or cause the loading or unloading of boxes, crates, containers, building materials, trash cans, dumpsters or similar objects between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. if the noise generated by such activity is likely to annoy, disturb, injure or endanger the comfort, repose, health, peace, safety, convenience, welfare or prosperity of any person. 
(4)  Compressors. No person shall operate or cause to be operated any compressor or mobile refrigeration unit or similar type of equipment or machinery between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. if the noise generated by such equipment or machinery is likely to annoy, disturb, injure or endanger the comfort, repose, health, peace, safety, convenience, welfare or prosperity of any person. This subsection shall apply to any stationary tractor-trailer unit that is required to operate due to its load or cargo. 
(g)  Exceptions. The provisions of subsections (e) and (f) of this section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Any person who is making, creating, causing, allowing or continuing any noise generated by any equipment, machinery or amplifying device when such person is engaged in a parade, carnival, circus, festival, fireworks display or similar public function approved by the town council or town administrator. 
(2)  Noises resulting from activities of a temporary duration permitted by law and for which a license or permit therefor has been granted by the town, if required. 
(3)  Any warning signals or devices intended to inform other persons of an emergency; or critical status of a building or facility provided such signal or device is reasonably terminated after it has accomplished its purpose. 
(4)  Any person operating an emergency vehicle while responding to an emergency call or while actively engaged in an emergency situation. 
(5)  Noises resulting from emergency work or required maintenance work performed by authorized personnel employed by or requested by the town. 
(6)  Bells or chimes while being used for religious purposes or in conjunction with religious services and those bells and chimes used for a similar legitimate purpose. However, if such bells or chimes are used for an extended and unreasonable period of time between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., such exception does not apply. 
(7)  Snow-clearing equipment, including, but not limited to, snowblowers and snowplowing equipment. 
(Ord. No. 99-04,  1.0-7.0, 12-1-1999) 
Sec. 20-7. - Sale of rolling papers to minors. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Minor means any person who is under the age of 18 years. 
    Rolling papers means any paper product that is designed to encase or wrap tobacco or similar products and marketed for the purpose of smoking or manufacturing hand-rolled cigarettes. 
(b)  Sales and possession. 
(1)  No person or place of business shall sell, give or furnish rolling papers to minors. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any minor to possess or attempt to purchase rolling papers. 
(Prior Code,  14.3.1, 14.3.2; Ord. No. 2003-10, 8-20-2003) 
Sec. 20-8. - Curbside pickup of domestic or household waste and recyclables. 
(a)  General. 
(1)  Purpose and intent. The proper management of waste is in the public welfare of the community. Poorly managed trash, rubbish and waste can attract rodents, diminish aesthetic qualities, become a public nuisance, and adversely affect the public, health, safety, and welfare. 
(2)  Limitations. The town shall only pick-up and dispose of those household and domestic solid waste materials and recyclables generated within the geographic boundaries of the town. Disposal of such waste shall be at a site designated and authorized by the town council. 
(3)  Authority to establish rules and regulations. The town council shall be solely authorized and responsible for establishing, amending, and revising such rules, regulations and procedures as are necessary for the implementation and execution of the purpose and intent of this section and the effective operation of the curbside pickup and recyclables program, unless said authority has otherwise been delegated to an agent of the town council. 
(b)  Definitions. 
(1)  Domestic or household waste. Solid waste comprised of garbage and rubbish normally associated with residential household use and originating in residential households. 
(2)  Commercial waste. All solid waste emanating from business establishments including, but not limited to, solid waste originating in stores, markets, office buildings, industrial complexes, restaurants, theaters, landscapes, automotive service centers, service businesses, and shopping centers. 
(3)  Waste. All domestic, household, and commercial waste, as those terms are defined herein. 
(4)  Recyclables. Materials to be collected as part of the town's recycling program shall be defined by the health officer and approved by the town council. 
(5)  Official plastic bags. Specially marked trash bags as made available by the town for purchase by Newmarket residents. Only such bags shall be utilized to dispose of all permitted waste (excluding recyclables) at curbside. 
(6)  Blue box. Receptacles provided by the town residents to be used for the placement of recyclables within the public right-of-way. The town shall provide one blue box to each residence. If additional blue boxes are requested, they may be purchased from the town at cost. Blue boxes shall constitute the property of the town. 
(c)  Prohibited collection materials. 
    The following materials shall not be placed in the official plastic bags, nor will such materials be picked up as recyclables: 
Acids and alkalis Animal carcasses, manure and meats Container with liquid contents Tires Flammable liquids Mercury vapor lamps Pesticides Paints Solvents, oils and thinners Asbestos materials Mercury thermostats and switches Ammunition and explosives Medical/dental wastes Septage Textile waste Wood Nuclear related waste Roofing cement Hazardous waste as defined by state and federal agencies Chlorine cleaners, swimming pool disinfectants Bulky items, such as furniture, televisions, bicycles, bedsprings, washers, etc., as determined by the public works director Lawn cuttings, trees and shrub limbs, garden waste Any waste deemed to be inappropriate by the public works director  
(d)  General provisions. 
(1)  No person shall deposit or cause to be deposited any refuse or waste, upon the rights-of-way of accepted roadways within the town, except that refuse or waste which may be deposited for collection under this ordinance within the town right-of-way and confined within a closed official plastic bag or town issued blue box. 
(2)  Official plastic bags and town issued blue boxes shall be placed on the outside of the sidewalk and/or near as practicable to the street edge, no more than 12 hours prior to collection day. Persons placing official plastic bags and town issued blue boxes at the curbside more than 12 hours prior to collection day may be issued a summons for littering pursuant to RSA chapter 163-B. Empty blue boxes shall be removed from the public right-of-way no later than 6:00 p.m. on the day of collection. Waste, official plastic bags, town issued blue boxes, and other waste containers and recycling materials shall be screened from public view until no more than 12 hours prior to collection day. Screening shall be complete with no portion of the waste, official plastic bags, town issued blue boxes, and other waste containers and recycling materials visible from a public way. 
(3)  The town shall pickup no more than three, 33-gallon official plastic bags per address per pick-up. Residents shall only place household waste in official plastic bags. The town shall only pick up household waste contained in official plastic bags. All bags must be closed and tied. No bag shall have a gross weight of more than 30 pounds. Official plastic bags can be purchased at the town hall or at the local retail stores. The price of each official plastic bag will be set by the town council based upon collection and disposal costs. 
(4)  Recyclables. The town council, with the suggestion of the health officer, shall determine the household waste that shall constitute recyclables suitable for pick up by the town. The town shall inform residents of household waste that constitute recyclables and that will be accepted by the town. Recyclables will be picked up on the regular household waste pick-up days for each residential unit. If unauthorized materials are found in the blue boxes, either the entire contents of the blue box or the unauthorized material, at the contractor's option, may be left at curbside. 
(5)  All recyclables may be placed in a blue box at curbside next to any official plastic bag on the day of collection, for collection. 
(6)  Regular collections start at 7:00 a.m. each day, in each collection zone. 
(7)  There will be no return trips for pick-up service. 
(8)  Upon placement at the curbside of town issued blue boxes, all materials placed and contained in such blue boxes shall become town property and shall not be removed by any person, except by persons authorized by the town or the person(s) responsible for placing the recyclables in the blue box. 
(e)  Dumpster users. For those multi-family and commercial properties which have private trash removal, recyclables may be placed in a blue box container at the curbside. 
(f)  Commercial waste disposal permit. Pursuant to RSA 149-M:17, II(a), the town council hereby authorized the town administrator to establish bylaws for the registration of haulers of commercial waste who haul solid commercial waste generated and collected within the geographic boundaries of the town. Said registration shall be evidenced by a commercial waste disposal permit issued by the town. 
(g)  Penalty. 
(1)  The town, or its agent, reserves the right to refuse to collect garbage, rubbish, recyclables or other refuse which does not comply with the requirements of this section. 
(2)  Any person who violates any provision of this ordinance shall be guilty of a violation and shall be subject to a fine of not more than $1,000.00 pursuant to RSA 147:1, RSA 625:9, V-a, and RSA 651:2, IV. Each day that a violation of this section exists shall constitute a separate violation. 
(3)  The health officer, chief of police and/or the director of public works, or their designees, are hereby authorized to order the removal of any materials deposited in violation of this ordinance, and any person who shall fail to comply with such order shall be responsible for reimbursing the town for any and all costs associated with said removal and subject to a fine as specified herein. 
(h)  Improper waste disposal; enforcement; penalty. 
(1)  Notwithstanding any provision of this ordinance to the contrary, waste not enclosed by an official plastic bag or deposited in a blue box shall be subjected to the following penalty/corrective action: 
a.  For an initial violation, the owner or resident shall be notified in writing of the violation and the town may, in its sole discretion, refuse to accept the waste. In the event that the town refused the waste, the owner or resident shall take corrective action(s), which shall include, but not limited to, removal of said waste from the rights-of-way or curb within six hours of receipt of said notice. 
b.  For a second violation, the town shall refuse to collect the waste and the owner or resident shall be notified that all the material not in the official plastic bag shall be removed within six hours or receipt of said notice. The owner or resident may place appropriate household waste in an official plastic bag and put said official plastic bag out for collection on the next scheduled collection day in full compliance with this section. 
c.  For the third and subsequent violations within a 12 month period, the owner or resident shall be notified of the violation, and the town shall assess an administrative penalty of $150.00 to the property owner or resident. The director of public works, who is hereby authorized by the town council, may inform the owner or resident that collection service shall be discontinued until such time as corrective actions are taken and until such time as the owner or resident pays said penalty assessment to the town. 
(Ord. No. 2015/2016-2, 1-20-2016) 
Chapter 22 - PARKS, RECREATION AND CONSERVATION AREAS[1] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference- Public recreation and parks, RSA 35-B. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Leo Landroche Field rules. 
(a)  The Leo Landroche Field shall be closed to all individuals when there are no scheduled events at dusk. Town-sponsored events will be exempt from this curfew time. 
(b)  Should there be a scheduled event at the Leo Landroche Field and Park amenities, all participants shall vacate the property within one-half hour of the conclusion of such activity. 
(c)  The police department shall monitor the field and have the power to make an arrest of any individual who violates the regulations of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2008/09-01, 7-16-2008) 
Sec. 22-2. - Prohibited and allowed activities for the use of Pocket Park. 
    The following rules apply to the use of the town Pocket Park: 
(1)  No pets in the gardens; 
(2)  Do not leave children unattended; 
(3)  No smoking; 
(4)  No vandalism; 
(5)  Put recyclables in bins; 
(6)  No littering; 
(7)  Clean up after pets; 
(8)  Do not touch the electrical box; 
(9)  Do not climb on the rocks, trees, or tables; 
(10)  No disruptive noises; 
(11)  No riding bikes; 
(12)  Be respectful towards others; 
(13)  Do not leave personal possessions behind; 
(14)  Please leave the flowers for everyone to enjoy; 
(15)  Pick up after yourself. 
(Ord. No. 2009/2010-08, 6-16-2010) 
Secs. 22-3-22-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONSERVATION PROPERTY 

Sec. 22-23. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to ensure that all conservation property owned by the town is maintained as a healthful and attractive outdoor environment for the public benefit. This article does not supersede article III of this chapter regarding rules and regulations governing the use of the Heron Point Sanctuary. 
(Prior Code,  12.2.1; Ord. No. 99-05, 1-5-2000; Ord. No. 2004-07, 7-4-2004) 
Sec. 22-24. - Prohibited and allowed activities. 
(a)  Except for parking in designated areas, there shall be no parking or vehicular traffic, bicycles or skateboards on the properties, which shall be restricted to foot traffic only. 
(b)  There shall be no camping, campfires or overnight use of the property unless allowed by the conservation commission, as a whole, for civic groups (i.e., Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts). 
(c)  No removal, filling or other disturbances of the soil surface, nor changes in topography, surface or subsurface water systems, wetlands, or natural habit shall be allowed unless such activities: 
(1)  Are commonly necessary in the accomplishment of the forestry, conservation, or habitat management and are authorized by the conservation commission; 
(2)  Do not harm state or federally recognized rare or endangered species, such determination of harm to be based upon information from the state natural heritage inventory or the agency then recognized by the state as having responsibility for identification and/or conservation of such species; and 
(3)  Are not detrimental to the purpose of this article. 
(d)  There shall be no mining, quarrying, excavation or extraction of rocks, minerals, gravel, sand, topsoil or other similar materials on the property. No such rocks, minerals, gravel, sand, topsoil, or other similar materials shall be removed from the property. 
(e)  There shall be no dumping, injection, or burial of materials then known to be environmentally hazardous, including vehicle bodies or parts. 
(f)  There shall be hunting or trapping on the properties wherein hunting and trapping is allowed as prescribed per state fish and game regulations. 
(g)  No person shall engage in any disorderly conduct or disruptive behavior which creates a breach of the peace through unreasonable noises, derisive or offensive words, fighting or violent behavior, or other conduct which is likely to cause alarm or annoyance to another person of average sensibilities or legitimate concern to any duly authorized police officer. Any person found within a town-owned conservation area engaged in any type of disorderly or disruptive behavior may be ordered to leave by any duly authorized police officer. Any person found trespassing or engaging in any unlawful conduct is subject to arrest. 
(h)  No person shall litter within or cause any damage within any portion of town-owned conservation areas. In addition, no person shall be found smoking any kind of tobacco products or found to possess any quantity of alcoholic beverage within any town-owned conservation area. The responsible party must remove material of any type or quantity brought onto any town conservation area unless prior written permission by the conservation commission duly authorizes the items remaining. 
(i)  No person shall violate chapter 4, article II, regarding the regulation of dogs. This shall include but not be limited to section 4-29 (Removal of animal excrement required), which states: 
    Any person who owns or is responsible for an animal shall, if the animal defecates upon public property or private property, promptly clean up and dispose of the excrement. The excrement shall be disposed of in a lawful and sanitary manner. 
(j)  No person shall trespass within any town-owned conservation property from dusk to dawn unless authorized by the town council to do so. 
(Prior Code,  12.2.2; Ord. No. 99-05, 1-5-2000; Ord. No. 2004-07, 7-4-2004; Ord. No. 2006-07, 11-1-2006) 
Sec. 22-25. - Activities by permit. 
(a)  Civic groups whose membership consists primarily of town residents may apply to the conservation commission for a permit to camp overnight on conservation land. The conservation commission is authorized to develop appropriate regulations and guidelines on the use of conservation land for overnight camping. 
(b)  A permit request for an overnight stay must be obtained from the town administrator's office and submitted to the conservation commission prior to the date requested and in time for the conservation commission's monthly meeting. The conservation commission meets the fourth Thursday of every month. 
(Prior Code,  12.2.3; Ord. No. 99-05, 1-5-2000; Ord. No. 2004-07, 7-4-2004) 
Sec. 22-26. - Penalty. 
    Any person found violating section 22-24 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Prior Code,  12.2.4; Ord. No. 99-05, 1-5-2000; Ord. No. 2004-07, 7-4-2004) 
Secs. 22-27-22-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - HERON POINT SANCTUARY 

Sec. 22-56. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to ensure that Heron Point Sanctuary is maintained as a healthful and attractive outdoor environment for the public's benefit. 
(Ord. No. 97-3,  1, 10-1-1997) 
Sec. 22-57. - Prohibited activities. 
(a)  Except for parking in designated areas, there shall be no parking or vehicular traffic, bicycles or skateboards on the property which shall be restricted to foot traffic only. 
(b)  There shall be no camping, campfires or overnight use of the property. 
(c)  No removal, filling or other disturbances of the soil surface, nor any changes in topography, surface or subsurface water systems, wetlands, or natural habitat shall be allowed unless such activities: 
(1)  Are commonly necessary in the accomplishment of the forestry, conservation, or habitat management uses of the property; 
(2)  Do not harm state or federally recognized rare or endangered species, such determination of harm to be based upon information from the state natural heritage inventory or the agency then recognized by the state as having responsibility for identification and/or conservation of such species; and 
(3)  Are not detrimental to the purposes of this article. 
(d)  There shall be no mining, quarrying, excavation or extraction of rocks, minerals, gravel, sand, top soil or other similar materials on the property. No such rocks, minerals, gravel, sand, topsoil, or other similar materials shall be removed from the property. 
(e)  There shall be no dumping, injection, or burial of materials then known to be environmentally hazardous, including vehicle bodies or parts. 
(f)  There shall be no hunting or trapping on the property. 
(g)  No person shall engage in any disorderly conduct or disruptive behavior which creates a breach of the peace through unreasonable noises, derisive or offensive words, fighting or violent behavior, or other conduct which is likely to cause alarm or annoyance to another person of average sensibilities or legitimate concern to any duly authorized police officer. Any person found within the area designated as the Heron Point Sanctuary engaged in any type of disorderly conduct or disruptive behavior may be ordered to leave by any duly authorized police officer. 
(h)  No person shall litter within or cause any damage within any portion of the area designated as the Heron Point Sanctuary. In addition, no person shall be found smoking any type of tobacco products or found to be possessing any quantity of alcoholic beverages within the area designated as the Heron Point Sanctuary. 
(i)  No person shall violate any section of chapter 4, article II, regarding the regulation of dogs. This shall include but not be limited to section 4-29 (Removal of animal excrement required) which states: 
    Any person who owns or is responsible for an animal shall, if the animal defecates upon public property or private property, promptly clean up and dispose of the excrement. The excrement shall be disposed of in a lawful and sanitary manner. 
(j)  No person shall trespass within the Heron Point Sanctuary from dusk to dawn unless authorized by the town council to do so. 
(Ord. No. 97-3,  2, 10-1-1997) 
Sec. 22-58. - Penalty. 
    Any person found violating section 22-57 shall be guilty of violation and may be fined up to $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 97-3,  3, 10-1-1997) 
Chapter 24 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Planning and zoning, RSA 672-678. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Zoning ordinance amendment procedures. 
    All amendments to the zoning ordinance shall be made in accordance with the following procedures: 
(1)  Submission to planning board . Other than changes to the zoning ordinance proposed by the planning board, all requests for amendments to the zoning ordinance, which shall be presented to the town council, shall be referred to the planning board for its consideration. The planning board shall submit its recommendations concerning such requests to the council within 90 days after the referral has been made by the town council. 
(2)  Planning board hearing. The planning board, in its sole discretion, may hold a public hearing on the proposed amendment before making its recommendation to the town council. 
(3)  Planning board initiative . The planning board may, upon its own initiative, from time to time, consider amendments to the zoning ordinance and submit recommendations thereon to the town council. 
(4)  Ordinance form . The recommendations of the planning board made pursuant to subsection (1) of this section, or any amendment proposed by the planning board, shall be submitted to the town administrator who shall be responsible for putting the amendment into proper ordinance form beginning with the words "The Town of Newmarket Ordains ...." Whenever possible, the town administrator shall set out in full the ordinance, sections or subsections to be repealed or amended, and shall indicate the matter to be omitted by enclosing it in brackets or by strike-out type, and shall indicate new matter by underscoring it or by italics. 
(5)  Agenda . The ordinance shall be placed on the agenda of the town council for first reading. 
(6)  First reading. If the town council votes to pass the language of the ordinance at first reading, it shall be scheduled for a public hearing before the council. If the council votes not to pass at first reading, the proposed amendments die. 
(7)  Notice. Notice shall be given for the time and place of the public hearing at least ten days before the hearing. The notice required under this section shall not include the day the notice is posted or published, or the day of the public hearing. Notice of each public hearing shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the town and shall be posted in at least two public places. 
(8)  Text of ordinance . The full text of the proposed amendment to the zoning ordinance need not be included in the notice if an adequate statement describing the proposal and designating a place where the proposal is on file for public inspection in stated in the notice. 
(9)  Revisions. After the public hearing, the town council may make editorial revisions and textual modifications resulting from the proceedings of that hearing, so long as the proposed amendment remains substantially the same as that which was advertised for the public hearing. 
(10)  Additional public hearing after revisions. An additional public hearing shall be held if the proposal is substantively altered by the town council after the public hearing. Subsequent public hearings shall be held at least 14 days after the prior public hearing and with ten days' notice which shall not include the date of posting and the date of the hearing. 
(11)  Recording of amendment. If passed by the town council, the ordinance amendment shall be recorded, authenticated, indexed, printed, and published in accordance with the provisions of the town Charter. 
(Ord. No. 2009/2010-03, 10-7-2009) 
Secs. 24-2-24-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS PLAN[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Capital improvements program, RSA 674:5 et seq. 

Sec. 24-21. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide input to the town council pursuant to section 5.7(A) of the town Charter, by providing for the preparation a proposed capital improvements program. This input shall encompass major projects being currently undertaken or future projects to be undertaken with federal, state, county and other public funds along with all other project needs of department/division heads and other boards. The sole purpose and effect of the capital improvements program shall be to aid the town council and the budget committee in their consideration of the annual budget. 
(Prior Code,  2.10.1; Ord. No. 2004-06, 5-4-2004) 
Sec. 24-22. - Financial policies for management of debt and capital improvements. 
(a)  Borrowing funds. 
(1)  Long-term bonds or notes shall not be used to fund current maintenance and operational expenditures (RSA 33:3). 
(2)  Debt repayment plans, including lease-purchase agreements, will not exceed the expected useful life of the improvement financed. 
(3)  Tax and revenue anticipation notes will not be issued to fund the capital improvement plan. 
(4)  Bond anticipation notes, pursuant to RSA 33:7-a, will mature each year and shall be repaid completely within five years. 
(5)  Net indebtedness at any one time shall not exceed three percent of the assessed valuation of the town pursuant to RSA 33:4-a. The issuance of bonds to install a sewerage system, sewage treatment works and water works that was ordered by the division of water and supply and pollution control is not considered in the net of the town for the purpose of ascertaining its borrowing capacity (RSA 33:4-a, 33:5, 33-5a). 
(b)  Current operational expenses and revenues. 
(1)  The department heads, the town administrator and the town council, on a yearly basis, shall review current capital expenditures. 
(2)  The water and sewer rates shall be annually reviewed by the town council to ensure the revenues are sufficient to fund the debt service requirements. 
(c)  Use of other funds. 
(1)  Capital reserves shall be utilized to fund capital expenditures. This form of financing shall be used to help fund vehicles and major building improvements even when a vehicle will not be acquired for a number of years past the six years incorporated within the CIP program. 
(2)  Unless restricted by the grant, grant funds from state and federal sources will be utilized to the fullest extent to fund capital improvements. 
(3)  Pursuant to RSA 674:21,V(c) impact fees will be used solely for the capital improvements for which they were collected or to recoup the cost of capital improvements made in anticipation of the needs which the fee was collected to meet. 
(Prior Code,  2.10.2; Ord. No. 2004-06, 5-4-2004) 
Sec. 24-23. - Capital improvement plan criteria. 
(a)  Pursuant to section 5.7 of the town Charter, the capital improvement plan shall include: 
(1)  A clear summary of its contents. 
(2)  A list of all capital improvements including major replacements which are proposed to be undertaken during the next six fiscal years, including, but not limited to, equipment, sewer and water mains or facilities, roads, sidewalks, bicycle paths or lanes, public open spaces and recreation facilities, new police and/or fire stations, and other new public facilities and major items of equipment. 
(3)  A clarification of projects, according to the urgency and need for realization. 
(4)  Cost estimates, methods of financing and recommended time schedule for each such improvement. 
(5)  The estimated annual cost of operating and maintaining the facilities to be constructed or acquired. 
(6)  A continuation of the long-term financial planning projections already provided in the current capital improvements program to avoid unexpected increases in the municipal property tax rate. 
(7)  All studies that pertain to capital improvements done for the town in order to preserve that data for the future. This data can be revised from time to time as warranted. 
(b)  The capital improvement plan shall be based on a period of not less than six years and shall include reference to or be influenced by, where appropriate, the town master plan. 
(c)  The information in this section may be revised and extended each year with regard to capital improvements still pending or in process of construction or acquisition. 
(Prior Code,  2.10.3; Ord. No. 2004-06, 5-4-2004) 
Sec. 24-24. - Committee. 
(a)  The capital improvements plan committee shall consist of five members and two alternates appointed by the town council as follows: 
(1)  Regular members. 
a.  One town councilmember. 
b.  One planning board member. 
c.  One budget committee member. 
d.  Finance director. 
e.  Planner. 
(2)  Alternates. 
a.  One planning board member. 
b.  One budget committee member. 
(b)  The town council will ratify all appointments of each board. The appointments will be done on an annual basis. 
(c)  Meetings. The committee shall meet as necessary to elect a chairman and other officers as deemed necessary, and to set their agenda, as appropriate. 
(d)  Posting meetings. All meetings are to be posted by the town administrator's office and subject to RSA 91-A. 
(e)  Minutes of meetings. Minutes of approved meetings shall be given to the town administrator's office on a disk in Word format so it can be posted on the town's website. 
(Prior Code,  2.10.4-2.10.7; Ord. No. 2004-06, 5-4-2004) 
Sec. 24-25. - Submittal. 
    The capital improvement plan will be submitted to the town council by November 15. 
(Prior Code,  2.10.8; Ord. No. 2004-06, 5-4-2004) 
Chapter 26 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Weight limits over town roads. 
(a)  Posted roads. Unless specifically permitted by the written directive of the public works director, it shall be unlawful for any person, partnership or corporation to haul, transport or cause to be transported by vehicles with gross weight over six tons any material over Class V roads in the town from 12:01 a.m., March 5 of each year through 11:59 p.m., April 30 of each year, or as determined necessary by the public works director. The dates as determined by the public works director shall be published once in a newspaper of general circulation and posted in at least two public places in the town. 
(b)  Applicability. This restriction shall not apply to emergency vehicles, fuel tankers delivering on the regulated roads, refuse collection vehicles collecting from regulated roads, public utility vehicles involved in emergency repair operations, town public works vehicles, or school buses operated by the school district. 
(Prior Code,  10.2.1, 10.2.2; Ord. No. 2001-02, 2-21-2001) 
Sec. 26-2. - Penalty. 
    In addition to the penalties set forth in section 1-7, any person, corporation or user who violates this chapter shall be liable to the town for all damages incurred to said highway caused by such violation. 
(Prior Code,  10.2.3; Ord. No. 2001-02, 2-21-2001) 
Secs. 26-3-26-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS, OBSTRUCTIONS AND CURBS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate use of highways, RSA 41:11. 

Sec. 26-21. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) means a set of national guidelines published under the auspices of the U.S. Department of Transportation, Federal Highway Administration. The purpose of the MUTCD is to provide uniform and systematic treatment of highway conditions, including construction zones, on a nationwide basis. 
    Temporary traffic control plan describes measures to be used for facilitating road users through a work zone. 
    Temporary traffic control signal means any device, whether manually, electrically or mechanically operated, by which traffic is alternately directed to stop and permitted to proceed. 
    Temporary traffic control zones means an area of a highway where road user conditions are changed because of a work zone through the use of temporary traffic control devices, uniformed law enforcement officers, certified flaggers or other authorized personnel. 
    Traffic means pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles, streetcars, and other conveyances either singly or together while using any way for purposes of travel. 
(Prior Code,  10:3.1; Ord. No. 2004-11, 5-5-2004) 
Sec. 26-22. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person found violating any section of this article, except section 26-31(b), shall be guilty of a violation and may be fined according to the provisions of section 1-7. 
(b)  Pursuant to RSA 265:3-b, any person found violating section 26-31(b) shall be guilty of a violation and may be fined not more than $100.00 for the first offense and not more than $250.00 for any subsequent offense committed during any calendar year. 
(Prior Code,  10:3.11; Ord. No. 2004-11, 5-5-2004) 
Sec. 26-23. - Enforcement. 
    The police department is authorized to take appropriate enforcement action of this article consistent with state law. A police officer who finds probable cause that any violation of this article has been committed may issue a summons to any person found in violation in lieu of arrest. 
(Prior Code,  10:3.12; Ord. No. 2004-11, 5-5-2004) 
Sec. 26-24. - Scope. 
    This article shall not apply to any work, obstruction, and/or encumbrance upon any state highway classified as a Class I, II or III involving the state or its subcontractors with respect to any work, obstruction or encumbrance caused for the benefit of the state. 
(Prior Code,  10:3.1; Ord. No. 2004-11, 5-5-2004) 
Sec. 26-25. - Excavations and obstructions; license required. 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation or agent or servant thereof shall excavate, obstruct or in any way encumber, including working within manholes and catchbasins, any street, sidewalk or other town-owned property or right-of-way in the town without first having obtained a written license to do so from the public works director or his designee of said town, except where such licensing power is particularly vested in the town council. 
(b)  Each and every such licensee shall coordinate each request to excavate, obstruct or encumber with the public works director, planner, code enforcement officer, police department, water/wastewater departments as required by the director of public works and as specified on a form issued by the public works department. 
(c)  Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this section shall be considered guilty of a violation. 
(Prior Code,  10:3.3; Ord. No. 2004-11, 5-5-2004) 
Sec. 26-26. - Scheduling of work. 
    The public works director shall specify the time and date for the work, which work may be required at nighttime, Saturdays, Sundays or holidays. Scheduling will be such as to not unreasonably interfere with traffic. 
(Prior Code,  10:3.4; Ord. No. 2004-11, 5-5-2004) 
Sec. 26-27. - Winter scheduling of construction work. 
    Except for emergencies as may be deemed essential by the director of public works, no person, firm or corporation, or any agent or servant thereof, shall excavate any street or sidewalk in the town between November 15 and April 15. 
(Prior Code,  10:3.5; Ord. No. 2004-11, 5-5-2004) 
Sec. 26-28. - Construction requirements. 
(a)  Traffic control plan. The public works director shall require a temporary traffic control plan from the licensee. 
(b)  The licensee shall provide proof of insurance for workers compensation, employer's liability and property liability for vehicles. Both the employer's liability and the property liability (vehicle) insurance shall be for the amount of $1,000,000.00 each. 
(c)  The licensee shall erect and maintain suitable barricades with flashers or lanterns so long as public safety and convenience requires. 
(d)  The licensee must provide a safe and convenient pedestrian way to the satisfaction of the public works director. 
(e)  The licensee is required to use materials, do the work, backfill and replace pavement in accordance with town standards as specified by the public works director. 
(f)  The repair of sidewalks shall be accomplished using the same material as the rest of the sidewalk, and no ragged joints will be allowed. 
(g)  The licensee is required to keep the work in good repair for a period of one year. 
(h)  The licensee, failing so to do after written notice from the public works director, shall be liable for the cost of any required repairs. 
(Prior Code,  10:3.6; Ord. No. 2004-11, 5-5-2004) 
Sec. 26-29. - Inspections. 
(a)  The public works director or his designee shall inspect the site prior to the commencement of backfill, during the backfill operation, prior to the commencement of paving and during the paving operation. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the licensee to arrange for these inspections and the licensee shall provide a 48-hour notice. 
(Prior Code,  10:3.7; Ord. No. 2004-11, 5-5-2004) 
Sec. 26-30. - Traffic control plans. 
    The public works director shall require and approve, approve with conditions, or deny a temporary traffic control plan, which conforms to the latest edition of the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) Part 6, Temporary Traffic Control. The temporary traffic control plan shall be developed to provide safety for motorists, bicyclists, pedestrians, workers, enforcement/emergency officials, and equipment, with the following factors being considered: 
(1)  The basic safety principles governing the design of permanent roadways and roadsides should also govern the design of the temporary traffic control plan zones. The goal should be to route road users through such zones using roadway geometrics, roadside features, and temporary traffic control devices as nearly as possible comparable to those for normal highway situations. 
(2)  A temporary traffic control plan, in detail appropriate to the complexity of the work project, should be prepared and understood by all responsible parties before the site is occupied. The public works director should approve any changes in the temporary traffic control plan. 
(3)  In the temporary traffic control plan, a provision will be set forth to allow police officers, flag persons (certifications need to be included), or a combination of both to provide temporary traffic control signals. 
(Prior Code,  10:3.8; Ord. No. 2004-11, 5-5-2004) 
Sec. 26-31. - Other requirements related to temporary traffic control zones. 
(a)  Obedience to any required traffic control devices. Pursuant to RSA 265:9, the driver of any vehicle shall obey the instructions of any temporary traffic control devices applicable thereto as provided by law, unless otherwise directed by a traffic or police officer, subject to the exceptions granted the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle in RSA 265. 
(b)  Obedience to flag persons. Pursuant to RSA 265:3-b, the driver of any vehicle shall obey the instructions of any flag person in the act of directing, controlling, or regulating traffic within any construction, maintenance, or utility work area indicated by official traffic control devices. If the flag person is displaying a signal to stop, the driver of a vehicle upon a way shall stop the vehicle at least 25 feet before reaching such flag person. The driver shall not proceed until the flag person indicates that traffic may proceed and until the driver may do so safely. 
(c)  Display of unauthorized signs, signals or markings. Pursuant to RSA 265:14, no person shall place, maintain or display upon or in view of any way any unauthorized sign, signal, marking or device or railroad sign or signal, which purports to be or is an imitation of or resembles an official traffic control device, or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic, or which hides from view or interferes with the effectiveness of any official traffic control device. No person shall place or maintain nor shall any public authority permit upon any way any traffic sign or signal bearing thereon any commercial advertising. This subsection shall not be deemed to prohibit the erection upon private property adjacent to ways of signs giving useful directional information and of a type that cannot be mistaken for official signs. If an unauthorized sign, signal or marking is found then every such prohibited sign, signal or marking is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and the authority having jurisdiction over the way is hereby empowered to remove the same or cause it to be removed without notice. 
(Prior Code,  10:3.9; Ord. No. 2004-11, 5-5-2004) 
Sec. 26-32. - Deposit required; bonding. 
    Whenever the public works director shall grant any person, firm or corporation permission to excavate in any street, sidewalk or other town-owned property, in granting such permission, the public works director shall require the requesting party to furnish a bond to be held by the town for ten percent of the construction project cost or whatever is deemed prudent by the public works director. This bond will be retained for one year after the project is completed. This bond enables the town to complete construction of any project granted by this license if the licensee fails to complete the project. 
(Prior Code,  10:3.10; Ord. No. 2004-11, 5-5-2004) 
Secs. 26-33-26-52. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALK CAFES 

Sec. 26-53. - Permit standards. 
    A sidewalk cafe is permitted as an extension of any permitted restaurant after demonstration of compliance with the following standards: 
(1)  A detailed plan of the proposed seating arrangement and layout of pedestrian corridors; pedestrian corridors for sidewalk use and restaurant access shall be maintained in a manner that does not disrupt pedestrian traffic flow and have an unobstructed travel way that is a minimum of 36 inches in width; 
(2)  Seats and tables shall be structurally sound; 
(3)  Placement of a sidewalk cafe or outdoor seating shall be limited to the area of sidewalk directly in front of the restaurant establishment; 
(4)  Provide proof of a $1,000,000.00 liability insurance policy, which names the town as a co-insured entity; 
(5)  Location of the seats and tables will not jeopardize the health, safety, license and welfare of the general public and tables and chairs shall be placed not closer than two feet to the sidewalk curb; 
(6)  Tables, chairs, and benches shall be allowed year-round; however, tables, chairs and benches shall be removed from the sidewalk nightly and stored inside the restaurant establishment; and 
(7)  Permittees shall be responsible to maintain the orderly placement and cleanliness of the area in front of their establishment. Permittees shall ensure that paper, dishware, flatware, cigarettes, etc., are removed from tables and the surrounding sidewalk so as to ensure the aesthetics of the area and downtown are maintained. 
(Ord. No. 2011/2012-01,  1, 4-18-2012) 
Sec. 26-54. - Duration. 
    Each sidewalk cafe area shall be permitted on a yearly basis. Request for renewals shall be evaluated at the time of permit payment and based on the previous year's compliance with the standards cited in section 26-53 and all other applicable local regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2011/2012-01,  2, 4-18-2012) 
Sec. 26-55. - Licensing process. 
(a)  License applications shall be made to the code enforcement officer, on forms prescribed by the town administrator. The application shall be reviewed based on the standards noted in section 26-53. 
(b)  The license application shall be acted upon within 30 days of submittal. If not acted on within that timeframe, the application will be considered approved. 
(c)  If the application is denied, the applicant shall be notified, in writing, within seven days of the denial. Such written notification will include an explanation of the reasons for denial. 
(d)  Each license granted under this article is granted on the condition that all provisions of this article shall be complied with. Any violation of any term of this article constitutes a violation of the conditional granting of the license itself. 
(e)  If the town believes that such a violation has occurred, the code enforcement officer shall notify the holder of the license in writing of the nature of the violation. 
(Ord. No. 2011/2012-01,  3, 4-18-2012) 
Sec. 26-56. - Licensing fees. 
    The license fees shall be $50.00, or as amended from time to time by action of the town council, and shall be paid by April 1 of each year. 
(Ord. No. 2011/2012-01,  4, 4-18-2012) 
Sec. 26-57. - Appeals. 
    Applicants may appeal the denial of an application to the town council. 
(Ord. No. 2011/2012-01,  5, 4-18-2012) 
Sec. 26-58. - Damage to obstructions. 
    Any damage by any cause whatsoever will be at the sole expense of the obstruction owner. 
(Ord. No. 2011/2012-01,  6, 4-18-2012) 
Sec. 26-59. - Hold harmless. 
    Every person or other entity which places or maintains an obstruction on a public sidewalk in the town shall file a written statement with the town clerk satisfactory to the town attorney, whereby he or it agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the town, its officers, councilmembers and employees, for bodily or personal injury, and for property damage sustained by any person as a result of the installation, use or maintenance of such obstruction. 
(Ord. No. 2011/2012-01,  7, 4-18-2012) 
Sec. 26-60. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be fined $100.00 for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 2011/2012-01,  10, 4-18-2012) 
Secs. 26-61-26-78. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SIDEWALK STANDS 

Sec. 26-79. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Stand means any push-cart, wagon or any other wheeled vehicle or device which may be moved without the assistance of a motor and which is not required to be licensed and registered by the department of motor vehicles, used for the displaying, storing on transporting of articles offered for sale by a vendor. 
    Vendor means a peddler who on public property sells food, beverages or merchandise from a stand or his person. 
(Ord. No. 2011/2012-02,  1, 5-2-2012) 
Sec. 26-80. - Application. 
(a)  License applications shall be made to the code enforcement officer on forms prescribed by the town administrator. The application shall include the following: 
(1)  The name, home and business address of the applicant, and the name and address of the owner, if other than the applicant of the business and of any stand to be used in the operation of the business. 
(2)  A description of the type of food, beverage or merchandise to be sold. 
(3)  A description and photograph of any stand to be used in the operation of the business. 
(4)  A certificate of insurance issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the state, protecting the licensee and the town from all claims for damages to property and bodily injury, including death, which may arise from operations under or in connection with the license. 
(b)  The insurance policy shall not be terminated or cancelled prior to the expiration date except with 30 days' advance written notice to the town. The policy shall provide combined single limit coverage in the amount of $1,000,000.00 for personal injury and property damage. The town shall be named as additional insured. 
(Ord. No. 2011/2012-02,  2, 5-2-2012) 
Sec. 26-81. - Licensing process. 
(a)  License applications shall be made to the code enforcement officer, on forms prescribed by the town administrator. The application shall be reviewed based on the standards noted in this article. 
(b)  The code enforcement officer shall provide a written report to the town council. 
(c)  The license application shall be presented to the council at their next regular meeting for review and disposition. 
(d)  The town council shall review the application and the report of the code enforcement officer at their next regularly scheduled meeting and either approve or deny the application at that time. If not acted on within that timeframe, the application will be considered approved. 
(e)  If the application is denied, the applicant shall be notified, in writing, within seven days of the denial. Such written notification will include an explanation of the reasons for denial. 
(f)  Each license granted under this article is granted on the condition that all provisions of this article shall be complied with. Any violation of any term of this article constitutes a violation of the conditional granting of the license itself. 
(g)  If the town believes that such a violation has occurred, the code enforcement officer shall notify the holder of the license in writing of the nature of the violation. 
(Ord. No. 2011/2012-02,  3, 5-2-2012) 
Sec. 26-82. - Licensing fee. 
    The license fee shall be $50.00, or as amended from time to time by action of the town council. 
(Ord. No. 2011/2012-02,  4, 5-2-2012) 
Sec. 26-83. - Duration. 
    Each vendor stand shall be permitted on a year-round basis. Request for renewals shall be evaluated based on the previous year's compliance with the standards cited in this article and all other applicable local regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2011/2012-02,  5, 5-2-2012) 
Sec. 26-84. - Hours of operation. 
    The hours of operation for each vendor stand shall be between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 2011/2012-02,  6, 5-2-2012) 
Sec. 26-85. - Prohibited conduct. 
(a)  A vendor shall not: 
(1)  Leave any stand unattended. 
(2)  Store, park, or leave any stand overnight on any street or sidewalk in conformance with town parking regulations. 
(3)  Sell food or beverages for immediate consumption unless he has available for public use his own litter receptacle which is available for his patrons' use. 
(4)  Leave any location without first picking up, removing and disposing all trash or refuse remaining from sales made by him. 
(5)  Allow any items relating to the operation of the vending business to be placed anywhere other than in, or under the stand, except as expressly indicated in the application for a license. 
(6)  Set up, maintain or permit the use of any table, crate, carton, rack, sign, or any other device to increase the selling or display capacity of his stand, where such items have not been described in his application. 
(7)  Solicit or conduct business with persons in motor vehicles. 
(8)  Sell anything other than that which he is licensed to vend. 
(9)  Sound or permit the sounding of any device which produces a loud and raucous noise, or use or operate any loudspeaker, public address system, radio sound amplifier or similar device to attract the attention of the public. 
(10)  Vend without a fire extinguisher of a type approved by the fire chief or his designee if the vendor utilizes heat generation equipment. 
(11)  Vend at any location where the unobstructed sidewalk area after deducting the area occupied by the stand is less than three feet in width. 
(12)  Vend within ten feet of any driveway. 
(13)  Allow the stand or any other item relating to the operation of the vending business to lean against or hang from any building or other structure lawfully placed on public property, without the owner's written permission. 
(b)  Vendors may petition the town council for specific relief from subsections (a)(3) through (14) of this section. The town council may undertake a site visit to the vendor's approved location to view the site as it would be operated. The town council will then vote to approve or disapprove the request at their next regular meeting. 
(Ord. No. 2011/2012-02,  7, 5-2-2012) 
Sec. 26-86. - Prohibited locations. 
    No stand shall be permitted in front of or on either side of the Veteran's Memorial Bandstand. This area shall be defined as the area between the north side pedestrian walkway to Rivermoor Landing to the south side pedestrian walkway to Rivermoor Landing. No stand shall be permitted in Schanda Park. No stand shall be permitted unless expressly permitted by the town council. 
(Ord. No. 2011/2012-02,  8, 5-2-2012) 
Sec. 26-87. - Appeals. 
    An applicant may appeal the denial of an application to the town council. 
(Ord. No. 2011/2012-02,  9, 5-2-2012) 
Sec. 26-88. - Damage or obstructions. 
    Any damage by any cause whatsoever will be at the sole expense of the obstruction owner. 
(Ord. No. 2011/2012-02,  10, 5-2-2012) 
Sec. 26-89. - Hold harmless. 
    Every person or other entity which places or maintains an obstruction on a public sidewalk in the town shall file a written statement with the town clerk satisfactory to the town attorney, whereby he or it agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the town, its officers, councilmembers and employees, for bodily or personal injury and for property damage sustained by any person as a result of the installation, use or maintenance of such obstruction. 
(Ord. No. 2011/2012-02,  11, 5-2-2012) 
Sec. 26-90. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be fined $100.00 for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 2011/2012-02,  14, 5-2-2012) 
Chapter 28 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Taxation, RSA 71-90. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 28-1. - Prepayment of taxes. 
    Prepayment of taxes is authorized in accordance with the provisions of RSA 80:52-a. 
(Prior Code,  2.14; Ord. No. 2006-08, 11-1-2006) 
Secs. 28-2-28-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - REAL PROPERTY TAX EXEMPTIONS 

Sec. 28-21. - Adoption of real property tax exemptions. 
    Pursuant to RSA 72:27-a, the town has adopted the following real property tax exemptions: 
(1)  Wood heating energy systems exemption; 
(2)  Solar energy systems exemption; and 
(3)  Wind-powered energy systems exemption. 
Sec. 28-22. - Wood heating energy systems exemptions. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Wood heating energy system means a wood-burning appliance designed to operate as a central heating system to heat the interior of a building. The appliance may burn wood solely or burn wood in combination with another fuel. A central heating system shall include a central appliance to distribute heat by a series of pipes, ducts or similar distribution system throughout a single building or group of buildings. A wood-burning appliance shall not include a fireplace, meaning a hearth, fire chamber or similarly prepared place with a chimney intended to be usable in an open configuration whether or not it may also be closed and operated closed; or a wood stove meaning a wood-burning appliance designed for space heating purposes which does not operate as a central heating system or as a sole source of heat. 
(b)  Criteria for exemption. The exemption will be given if it follows the prescribed definition of the wood heating energy system as described in subsection (a) of this section and all necessary applications and information has been received from the applicant. 
(c)  Amount of exemption. The exemption shall equal 100 percent of the cost of the system and its installation cost. 
(Prior Code,  2.11.1, 2.11.6, 2.11.7; Ord. No. 2006-02, 4-1-2006) 
State Law reference- Wood heating energy systems tax exemptions, RSA 72:69 et seq. 
Sec. 28-23. - Solar energy systems exemptions. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Solar energy system means a system which utilizes solar energy to heat or cool the interior of a building or to heat water for use in a building and which includes one or more collectors and a storage container. The term "solar energy system" also means a system which provides electricity for a building by the use of photovoltaic panels. 
(b)  Criteria for exemption. The exemption will be given if it follows the prescribed definition of the solar energy system as described in subsection (a) of this section and all necessary applications and information have been received from the applicant. 
(c)  Amount of exemption. The exemption shall equal 100 percent of the cost of the system and its installation cost. 
(Prior Code,  2.12.1, 2.12.6, 2.12.7; Ord. No. 2006-03, 4-1-2006) 
State Law reference- Solar energy systems tax exemptions, RSA 72:61 et seq. 
Sec. 28-24. - Wind-powered energy systems exemptions. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Wind-powered energy system means any wind-powered devices, which supplement or replace electrical power supplied to households or businesses at the immediate site. 
(b)  Criteria for exemption. The exemption will be given if it follows the prescribed definition of the wind-powered energy system as described in subsection (a) of this section and all necessary applications and information have been received from the applicant. 
(c)  Amount of exemption. The exemption shall equal 100 percent of the cost of the system and its installation cost. 
(Prior Code,  2.13.1, 2.13.6, 2.13.7; Ord. No. 2006-04, 4-1-2006) 
State Law reference- Wind-powered energy systems tax exemptions, RSA 72:65 et seq. 
Chapter 30 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, RSA 259-269. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Authority. 
    In accordance with the authority granted by RSA 41:11, 47:17 and 31:40, as amended, and any other applicable law, the ordinance from which this chapter is derived was enacted by the town council, or, when allowed by statute, by the town. 
(Prior Code,  11.2.1; Ord. No. 2000-02, 11-1-2000) 
Sec. 30-2. - Enforcement. 
    The chief of police, and his duly appointed agents, are hereby authorized to summons or arrest any person found in violation of this chapter. 
(Prior Code,  11.2.16; Ord. No. 2000-02, 11-1-2000) 
Sec. 30-3. - One-way traffic. 
    No person operating any motor vehicle on any public way within the town shall drive in a direction contrary to posted signs prohibiting such direction. The state department of transportation or the town department of public works may erect such signs. Such signs shall meet the specifications as determined by the state department of transportation and laws of the state. The following local public ways are designated for one-way traffic: 
(1)  Central Street (easterly from Spring Street to Main Street). 
(2)  Creighton Street (easterly from Main Street to Prescott Street). 
(3)  Short Street (westerly from Prescott Street to Exeter Street). 
(4)  Ham Street (easterly from Bay Road to Lamprey Street). 
(5)  Church Street (from the curve in the street at approximately 5 Church Street in a westerly direction to the intersection with Granite Street). 
(6)  Cedar Street (from the intersection of Elm Street to the intersection of Cedar Street in a northerly direction). 
(7)  Beech Street (from the intersection of Elm Street to the intersection of Cedar Street in a northerly direction). 
(8)  Salmon Street (from the intersection of Beech Street to the intersection of Piscassic Street in a westerly direction). 
(9)  Piscassic Street (from the intersection of Salmon Street to the intersection of Cedar Street in an easterly direction). 
(Prior Code,  11.2.2; Ord. No. 2000-02, 11-1-2000; Ord. No. 5-2017-2018,  2, 6-20-2018) 
Sec. 30-4. - Speed limits. 
(a)  The prima facie speed limit on all public ways within the town shall be 25 miles per hour except for the following: 
(1)  Route 108 otherwise known as "North Main Street, Main Street, Exeter Street and Exeter Road" shall be designated by the state department of transportation. Such speed limits shall be 30 miles per hour, 35 miles per hour or 40 miles per hour as posted. 
(2)  Route 152 otherwise known as "South Main Street or Wadleigh Falls Road" shall be designated by the state department of transportation. Such speed limits shall be 20 miles per hour within a school zone, 30 miles per hour, 35 miles per hour or 40 miles per hour as posted. 
(3)  The entire length of Packers Falls Road shall be 30 miles per hour or as designated by the state department of transportation and as posted. 
(4)  Grant Road from the intersection of South Main Street to the intersection of Schanda Drive shall be 35 miles per hour or as designated by the state department of transportation and as posted. 
(5)  Grant Road from the intersection of Schanda Drive to the Epping Town line shall be 30 miles per hour. 
(6)  The entire length of Ash Swamp Road shall be 30 miles per hour. 
(b)  No person shall drive a vehicle on a way at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions and having regard to the actual and potential hazards then existing. In every event speed shall be so controlled as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person, vehicle, or other conveyance on or entering the way in compliance with legal requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care. 
(c)  The penalties for any speeding violation shall be determined by the court of jurisdiction, which may impose a fine up to $1,000.00. 
(Prior Code,  11.2.15; Ord. No. 2000-02, 11-1-2000) 
State Law reference- Speed limits, RSA 265:50 et seq. 
Sec. 30-5. - Stop signs. 
    All persons operating any motor vehicle on any public way within the town shall stop at any posted stop sign erected by the state department of transportation or the town department of public works. Such signs shall meet the specifications as determined by the state department of transportation and laws of the state. The location of local signs on town-controlled ways shall be determined by the highway safety committee for the town and the town council shall be notified upon the erection of any such sign and may vote to repeal the said posting by majority vote (RSA 265:31). 
(Prior Code,  11.2.9; Ord. No. 2000-02, 11-1-2000) 
Sec. 30-6. - Yield signs. 
    All persons operating any motor vehicle on any public way within the town shall yield the right-of-way to any traffic at any posted "yield sign" erected by the state department of transportation or the town department of public works. Such signs shall meet the specifications as determined by the state department of transportation and laws of the state. The location of local signs on town-controlled ways shall be determined by the highway safety committee for the town and the town council shall be notified upon the erection of any such sign and may vote to repeal the said posting by majority vote (RSA 265:31). 
(Prior Code,  11.2.10; Ord. No. 2000-02, 11-1-2000) 
Sec. 30-7. - Alcohol prohibited in motor vehicles. 
(a)  Transportation and possession by driver and passenger. 
(1)  The words "liquor" and "beverage," as used in this subsection (a), shall have the same meanings as defined in RSA 175:1. 
(2)  Except as provided in subsection (a)(5) of this section, no driver shall transport, carry, possess, or have any liquor or beverage within the passenger area of any motor vehicle upon any way except in the original container and with the seal unbroken. Securely capped partially filled containers of liquor or beverages shall be stored and transported in the trunk of the motor vehicle. If the motor vehicle does not have a trunk, such containers shall be stored and transported in that compartment or area of the vehicle which is the least accessible to the driver.
