(3)  Except as provided in subsection (a)(5) of this section, no passenger shall carry, possess, or have any liquor or beverage within any passenger area of any motor vehicle upon any way or in an area principally used for public parking except in the original container and with the seal unbroken. Securely capped partially filled containers of liquor or beverages may be stored and transported in that compartment or area of the vehicle which is the least accessible to the driver. 
(4)  A person who violates this subsection (a) shall be guilty of a violation and shall be subject to a fine of $150.00. In addition, a person who violates subsection (a)(2) of this section may have his drivers' license, if a resident, or driving privilege, if a nonresident, suspended 60 days for a first offense and up to one year for a second or subsequent offense. 
(5)  This subsection (a) shall not apply to persons transporting, carrying, possessing, or having any liquor or beverage in a chartered bus, in a taxi, or in a limousine for hire; provided, however, that the driver of any of said vehicles is prohibited from having any liquor or beverage in or about the driver's area. 
(6)  For the purposes of this subsection (a) only: 
    Passenger area of any motor vehicle shall not include any section of a motor vehicle which has been designed or modified for the overnight accommodation of persons or as living quarters. 
    Way shall mean the entire width between the boundary lines of any public highway, street, avenue, road, alley, park, or parkway, or any private way laid out under authority of statute, or any such way provided and maintained by a public institution to which state funds are appropriated for public use or any such way which has been used for public travel for 20 years. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any alcohol beverages or to possess an open container of alcoholic beverages while on any town-owned property within the limits of the town, unless specific authorization has been granted by the town administrator or town council. 
(Prior Code,  11.2.11; Ord. No. 2000-02, 11-1-2000) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSA 265-A:44. 
Sec. 30-8. - Sidewalks. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bicycle means a vehicle with two tandem wheels, handlebars for steering, a saddle seat and pedals by which it is propelled. 
    Scooter means a vehicle consisting of a long footboard between two end wheels, controlled by an upright steering handle attached to the front wheel. 
    Sidewalk means that portion of a public highway between the curb and the adjacent property lines generally limited to pedestrian traffic. 
    Skateboard means a short, narrow board having one set of two or more wheels mounted under it. 
    Skates means any boot with wheels in pairs, or in a single file (roller blades), attached to the bottom of the boot. 
(b)  Established area. This section shall apply only to the entire length of Main Street and South Main Street within the town as herein described: from the intersection of Main Street and Elm Streets in a southerly direction (along route 108 to Route 152), to the intersection of South Main Street and Beech Street Extension inclusive of said intersections. This section shall include Chapel Street from the intersection of Main Street to the intersection of Granite Street. It shall further include Church Street from the intersection of Main Street to the intersection of Rock Street. 
(c)  Operation of bicycles, scooter, skateboard or skates. It shall be unlawful for any person having custody or control of any bicycle, scooter, skateboard or skates to ride or operate the said bicycle, scooter, skateboard or skates on any sidewalk within the established area. This shall not apply to persons with wheelchairs due to physical disability. 
(d)  Penalty. Any person having custody, control or ownership of any bicycle, skateboard or similar scooter within the established area; or any person found to be obstructing a sidewalk in a gathering of three or more people within the established area is guilty of a violation. Such person may be subject to a fine of not more than $1,000.00 pursuant to RSA 47:17 and as determined by any court. In addition, a person found violating this section may have a bicycle, skateboard or scooter impounded up to two days for the first violation and up to seven days for any subsequent violation. 
(Prior Code,  11.2.7, 11.2.8; Ord. No. 2000-02, 11-1-2000; Ord. No. 2009/2010-04, 12-16-2009) 
Sec. 30-9. - Road closing. 
    The town council authorizes the use of snow traveling vehicles only, on the town road known as Hersey Lane, emergency vehicles excepted, from December 1 to March 31 of every year. Said road shall be closed to all conventional motor vehicle traffic within these dates. Said road shall be closed from a point on the northerly end where the paved surface ends, traveling in a southerly direction to a point where the paved surface begins on the southerly end. 
(Prior Code,  11.2.14; Ord. No. 2000-02, 11-1-2000) 
Secs. 30-10-30-38. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing and parking, RSA 265:68 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 30-39. - Parking regulations. 
    Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device, no person, except a person driving an emergency vehicle, shall: 
(1)  Stop, stand or park a vehicle: 
a.  Beyond the posted time limits within a designated zone; 
b.  Within the posted and prohibited time periods within a designated zone; 
c.  Within a posted properly designated loading zone; 
d.  Within a posted and restricted parking zone which designates specific requirements or where official signs have been erected by town officials prohibiting such parking due to existing conditions; 
e.  Within a posted no parking zone; 
f.  Next to other parked vehicles so as to interfere with the egress of said vehicles or the normal flow of traffic; 
g.  In the wrong direction so that the tires of said vehicle are at the edge of a roadway or against the curb of a roadway in the opposite lane of travel; 
h.  Beyond painted lines, which are visible for a designated parking space; 
i.  Obstructing an alleyway; 
j.  On a sidewalk or crosswalk; 
k.  Within an intersection; 
l.  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within 30 feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of the safety zone; 
m.  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a way or within a highway tunnel; 
n.  Obstructing town officials engaged in any emergency operation; 
o.  Obstructing public works officials engaged in snow removal operations, street-cleaning operations, construction maintenance, road maintenance or other required functions. 
(2)  Stop, stand or park a vehicle on any public way within the town: 
a.  Upon any travel portion of any roadway so as to interfere with the normal flow of traffic; 
b.  Within a posted zone designated for fire apparatus; 
c.  Alongside or opposite any street excavation when stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic; 
d.  On any railroad tracks; 
e.  At any place where official signs prohibit stopping; 
f.  In any parking place, whether on public or private property, specially designated for a person with a walking disability by means of a sign as required by RSA 265:73-a stating that the space is reserved for a person with a walking disability or displaying the international accessibility symbol, unless that person has a special plate or placard issued or recognized pursuant to RSA 261:86 or RSA 261:88, and the person who qualifies for the plate or placard is being transported to or from the parking place. A person who violates the provisions of this subsection shall be fined a minimum of $250.00; 
g.  In the area between roadways of a divided highway, including crossovers; 
h.  In or overlapping into any access aisle. A person who violates the provisions of this subsection (2)h shall be fined a minimum of $50.00 for a first offense and a minimum of $100.00 for each subsequent offense. 
(3)  Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device, no person, except a person driving an emergency vehicle, shall: 
a.  Stand or park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except momentarily to pick up or discharge a passenger or passengers: 
1.  In front of a public or private driveway; 
2.  Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant; 
3.  Within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection; 
4.  Within 30 feet upon the approach to any flashing signal, stop sign, or traffic control signal located at the side of a roadway; 
5.  Within 20 feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within 75 feet of said entrance when properly signposted; 
6.  At any place where official signs prohibit standing. 
b.  Park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or passengers: 
1.  Within 50 feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing; 
2.  At any place where official signs prohibit parking. 
No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into any such prohibited area or away from a curb such a distance as is unlawful. 
(4)  Any person found violating any provisions as set forth in this section may, within seven days of a parking ticket being issued, pay a civil forfeiture in the following amount to the town in lieu of a court appearance for the said violation. All civil forfeiture payments shall be paid through the police department and forwarded to the town clerk's office. The amounts shall be as follows: 
a.  $20.00 for any violation in subsection (1) of this section. 
b.  $30.00 for a violation in subsection (2) of this section. 
(5)  Any person who fails to pay the civil forfeiture as prescribed in subsection (4) of this section within seven days of the ticket being issued and 30 days after being sent a notice of violation by mail to his last known address, according to the division of motor vehicles, shall be guilty of a violation if convicted by the court of jurisdiction of violating any provision set forth within this chapter and may be fined up to $1,000.00 and shall be fined not less or pay not less in civil forfeiture the following: 
a.  $30.00 for any violation in subsection (1) of this section. 
b.  $40.00 for any violation in subsection (2) of this section. 
(6)  Any person who believes that a parking ticket has been unlawfully issued may contest the said ticket at the police station before the chief of police or his designee within seven days of issuance. If it is determined that the ticket shall not be voided, a person may request an appearance before the court of jurisdiction. If requested, the person shall be provided with a summons for a court appearance. 
(7)  It shall be prima facie evidence and presumed that the registered owner, according to records of the motor vehicle division, shall be considered the person in violation of any provision within this section if his vehicle is found in violation of any said provisions. As used in this section, a public way shall mean any way for public use or any town-owned or town-maintained parking lot. 
(Prior Code,  11.2.3; Ord. No. 2000-02, 11-1-2000; Ord. No. 2-2016/2017,  2, 4-19-2017) 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing or parking prohibited in specific places, RSA 265:69. 
Sec. 30-40. - Water Street parking lot. 
    The municipal parking lot on Water Street will restrict parking from the hours of 1:00 a.m. to 5:00 a.m. all year round so as to accommodate public access to the Lamprey River for recreational purposes. Vehicles are prohibited from parking in the spaces that are designated for boat trailers only. 
(Prior Code,  11.2.1; Ord. No. 2000-02, 11-1-2000; Ord. No. 2006-01, 5-3-2006) 
Sec. 30-41. - Temporary no parking and traffic hazard signs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person having the custody, control or ownership of any vehicle to park or cause the same to be parked within the following areas of the town when designated by No Parking signs: 
(1)  Within 20 feet of any temporary No Parking sign authorized by an agent by the town. 
(2)  Within 20 feet of any warning device designating a traffic hazard or a danger to the public erected upon the authorization of the chief of police. 
(Prior Code,  11.2.5; Ord. No. 2000-02, 11-1-2000) 
Sec. 30-42. - Main Street/South Main Street parking. 
(a)  Established area. This section shall only apply to the entire length of Main Street and South Main Street within the town as herein described: From the intersection of Main Street and Elm Street in a southerly direction (along Route 108 to Route 152) to the intersection of South Main Street and Beech Street Extension, inclusive of said intersections. In addition, two parking spaces on Chapel Street at the intersection of Main Street will also be controlled by this chapter. This shall be considered the "established area" as outlined in this section. 
(b)  Two-hour parking. It shall be unlawful for any person having custody, control or ownership of any vehicle to park or cause to be parked on any public way within the established area for a period of time longer than two consecutive hours from 5:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Erected signs shall display such time periods where appropriate. Two-hour parking regulations on South Main Street from 5:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. daily may be exempt or waived when granted by the police department for a special function or event. 
(c)  Fifteen-minute parking. It shall be unlawful for any person having custody, control or ownership of any vehicle to park or cause to be parked any vehicle on Chapel Street between Main Street and Granite Street in designated areas limiting parking to no longer than 15 consecutive minutes. Such time limits shall be in effect daily from 5:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. Erected signs shall display such time periods where appropriate for a maximum of two parking spaces. 
(d)  Winter parking. Refer to subsection (g) of this section. 
(e)  Emergency restrictions. It shall be unlawful for any person having custody, control or ownership of any vehicle to park or cause to be parked any vehicle on any public way within the established area which interferes with snow removal operations or emergency street maintenance. The same restriction shall apply to conditions in cases of a natural disaster or emergency situation. Emergency signs or enforcement action may be invoked as deemed necessary by the town administrator, police chief or director of public works. 
(f)  Loading zone. It shall be unlawful for any person having custody, control or ownership of any vehicle to park or cause to be parked any vehicle on any public way within a designated area for the purposes of commercial loading or unloading. Such restrictions shall only apply during posted time limits. Erected signs shall display such designated areas and restrictions where appropriate. There shall be at least one and no more than two designated commercial loading and unloading zones within the said established area. 
(g)  Overnight parking. It shall be unlawful for any person having custody, control or ownership of any vehicle to park or cause to be parked any vehicle on any public way within the established area from the hours of 1:00 a.m. to 5:00 a.m. all year long. 
(h)  Handicapped zone. It shall be unlawful for any person having custody, control or ownership of any vehicle to park or cause to be parked any vehicle on any public way within the established area. There shall be at least one designated handicapped zone within the established area. A second handicapped zone in front of the Community Church on Main Street may be established on Sundays from 5:00 a.m. to 12:00 noon. 
(i)  Other restrictions. It shall be unlawful for any person having custody, control or ownership of any vehicle to park or cause to be parked any vehicle on any public way within the established area which violates any other provisions of town ordinances or state law. 
(j)  No parking zones. Unless specifically designated by road markings and painted lines, there shall be no parking within the established area and vehicles must be parked within such designated spaces identified by white road markings or painted lines. This shall also apply to restricted areas posted or identified by yellow road markings or painted lines. 
(Prior Code,  11.2.6; Ord. No. 2000-02, 11-1-2000; Ord. No. 2006-01, 5-3-2006) 
Sec. 30-43. - Night parking and snow removal. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person having custody, control or ownership of any vehicle to park or cause the same to be parked at any time between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. on any public street or highway or any area maintained and owned by the town so that said vehicle interferes or would interfere with snowplowing and/or snow removal operations of the town highway department between the dates of November 15 and March 31 of the following year, without a permit issued by the town. 
(Prior Code,  11.2.13; Ord. No. 2000-02, 11-1-2000; Ord. No. 2006-01, 5-3-2006; Ord. No. 2-2016/2017,  2, 4-19-2017) 
Secs. 30-44-30-74. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MISCELLANEOUS RESTRICTIONS 

Sec. 30-75. - Penalties. 
    When a vehicle is found in violation of any provisions of this division, the owner of said vehicle is subject to civil penalties through parking tickets and criminal penalties through fines in a court of competent jurisdiction. The owner of said vehicle is subject to a $20.00 civil fine through a parking ticket. Enhanced penalties may be assessed pursuant to RSA 231:132-a if the fine is not paid in a timely manner. A person found in violation of these provisions in criminal court may be fined a maximum of $1,000.00 if found guilty of such violation. In addition, any vehicle found violating these provisions might be towed at the owner's expense from the municipal parking lots. 
(Prior Code,  11.7.6; Ord. No. 2002-08, 1-15-2003; Ord. No. 2005-11, 12-7-2005) 
Sec. 30-76. - Library parking. 
    The municipal parking lot behind the town library shall have ten designated parking spaces allocated for the town library. Any person who owns or is in control of any vehicle that parks within a designated parking space for the use of the town library shall be employed by the library or attending the library. Any vehicle found in violation of this provision may be issued a parking ticket and is subject to being towed at the owner's expense. 
(Prior Code,  11.7.1; Ord. No. 2002-08, 1-15-2003; Ord. No. 2005-11, 12-7-2005) 
Sec. 30-77. - Free parking. 
    The municipal parking lots shall have designated parking spaces allocated for free parking during the daily hours of 6:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight. Local business owners, employees and patrons of the downtown business district may use such parking spaces, if available. Vehicles within the municipal parking lots may only park in designated free parking spaces and during specific time periods unless authorized to park in designated library spaces outlined in section 30-76 or unless authorized to park in designated permit spaces outlined in section 30-78. Any vehicle found in violation of this provision may be issued a parking ticket and is subject to being towed at the owner's expense. The following list of parking lots has the number of designated free parking spaces as listed below: 
(1)  Elm and Spring Street (behind the town library): 20 spaces. 
(2)  Railroad Street: six spaces. 
(Prior Code,  11.7.2; Ord. No. 2002-08, 1-15-2003; Ord. No. 2005-11, 12-7-2005) 
Sec. 30-78. - Permit parking. 
(a)  Designated lots and spaces. The municipal parking lots shall allow for permitted parking. These permits will allow any owner of a vehicle or person in control of any vehicle parked in a designated area between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. that requires a permit shall display the said permit in a manner established by the police department. Any vehicle found in violation of this provision may be issued a parking ticket and is subject to being towed at the owner's expense. Permits do not guarantee a parking space for a vehicle except during those hours. The following list of parking lots has the number of designated permitted spaces as listed below: 
(1)  Elm and Spring Street (behind the town library): 10 spaces. 
(2)  Railroad Street: seven spaces. 
(3)  Water Street Parking Lot: five spaces. 
(4)  Bay Road Lot: All spaces. 
(5)  29 Beech Street extension. 
(b)  Obtaining permit. The owner of a vehicle or the person in control of a vehicle who desires to park in designated permit parking spaces at the municipal parking lots must obtain a valid parking permit from the police department. An employee of the police department shall instruct the said owner or person in control of said vehicle as to how to display or affix such permit to his vehicle in order for it to be properly identified. Each parking permit shall be numbered and correspond to records maintained at the police department. Permits shall be issued to a specific person and not a particular vehicle. Any person found possessing or manufacturing a false town parking permit may be found guilty of a violation and is subject to penalties as prescribed in section 30-75. Any person found violating parking requirements established by the police department consistent with this section might have their permit revoked for just cause. Under such circumstances, the owner or person in control of said vehicle will not receive any reimbursement for any paid fees. Any parking requirements established by the police department shall be provided to the owner or person in control of such vehicle at the time the permit is issued. 
(c)  Permit duration. Permits shall be issued by the police department for the duration of six months commencing on January 1 and July 1 of each year. The said parking permits shall expire on June 30 and December 31 of each year unless otherwise renewed. 
(d)  Parking fee. 
(1)  Established; increases. Any person who desires to obtain a valid parking permit outlined in this section shall be required to pay a fee of $200.00 for each six-month period. Subsequent increases shall be effective only in January or July of each year and approved at the discretion of the town council. Parking spaces allotted are subject to revision at the discretion of the town council. However, permits issued shall not exceed the number of allotted spaces for permit parking. 
(2)  Overnight parking fee. The owner of a vehicle or the person in control of a vehicle may obtain an overnight parking permit which shall be valid from 12:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m. for a designated day. An overnight parking permit shall be $5.00 per day. Overnight parking permits shall be valid in the "free parking" zone and shall be color-coded to distinguish it from the other permits. Overnight parking permits shall be obtained and validated in the same manner as six-month permits. 
(3)  Monthly fee. The owner of a vehicle or the person in control of a vehicle may obtain a parking permit on a monthly basis instead of a six-month basis. Such monthly parking permits shall be $40.00 per month and shall only be valid from the first day to the last day of a given month. Monthly parking permits shall be obtained and validated in the same manner as six-month permits. 
(e)  Transferring permit. The owner or person in control of a vehicle who obtains a parking permit may transfer the said permit to another person prior to the expiration date of the permit provided he changes the required information with the police department and pays a $25.00 transfer fee. Said fee is subject to increases at the approval and discretion of the town council. 
(f)  Parking revenues. All received parking revenues as a result of this section shall be accounted for by the police department and delivered to the finance office. Such revenue shall be subject to town audit reports. 
(Prior Code,  11.7.3; Ord. No. 2002-08, 1-15-2003; Ord. No. 2005-11, 12-7-2005; Ord. No. 2-2016/2017,  2, 4-19-2017; Ord. No. 2-2017/2018,  2, 1-17-2018) 
Sec. 30-79. - Snow removal operations and emergency conditions. 
    Nothing within this division prevents the department of public works, fire and rescue or the police department from further regulating parking conditions within the municipal parking lots during snow removal operations or emergency conditions. As used in this section, the term "snow removal operations" means the time period from when three inches of snow accumulates and until the department of public works has completed the snow removal process. As used in this section, the term "emergency condition" shall be a bona fide emergency declared by the town administrator, police chief, fire chief or director of public works. Reasonable efforts shall be made to notify owners of parked vehicles within the municipal parking lots under such circumstances. 
(Prior Code,  11.7.4; Ord. No. 2002-08, 1-15-2003; Ord. No. 2005-11, 12-7-2005) 
Sec. 30-80. - Special events and other conditions. 
(a)  Special events. The municipal parking lots may be cleared in order to accommodate special events such as parades or other functions provided the town administrator or town council authorizes it. This shall not disrupt permit parking for greater than three days within a six-month period or parking fees shall be reimbursed on a prorated basis. 
(b)  Parking lot maintenance. The municipal parking lots may be cleared in order to accommodate maintenance required by the department of public works. 
(c)  Temporary restrictions. When temporary restrictions are invoked as a result of subsections (a) or (b) of this section, temporary signs will be erected at each entrance of the municipal parking lots affected, providing at least 24-hour notice of the pending restrictions. After such posting, any vehicle found in violation of such restrictions may be issued a parking ticket and towed at the owner's expense. Every reasonable measure will be taken to prevent any undue hardship on persons with parking permits. 
(d)  General restrictions. Any vehicle parked within the municipal parking lot shall be properly parked in designated parking spaces consistent with the regulations of this section. Any vehicle found clearly outside of the designated spaces marked by visible white painted lines or any vehicle creating an obstruction or hazard may be issued a parking ticket and towed at the owner's expense. 
(Prior Code,  11.7.5; Ord. No. 2002-08, 1-15-2003; Ord. No. 2005-11, 12-7-2005) 
Secs. 30-81-30-103. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BICYCLES, SKATEBOARDS AND SCOOTERS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Bicycles and mopeds, RSA 265:143 et seq.; bicycle ordinances, RSA 265:149. 

Sec. 30-104. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Scooter means a vehicle consisting of a long footboard between two end wheels, controlled by an upright steering handle attached to the front wheel. 
    Sidewalk means that portion of a public highway between the curb and the adjacent property lines generally limited to pedestrian traffic. 
    Skateboard means a short, narrow board having one set of two or more wheels mounted under it. 
    Way means any road, street, avenue, boulevard, court, parking lot or way legally accepted for maintenance and dedicated public use by the legislative authority of the state or by the town council. 
(Prior Code,  14.9.1; Ord. No. 2003-16, 8-20-2003) 
Sec. 30-105. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Any person 16 years of age or older found in violation of this article may be charged. 
(b)  In addition, any bicycle, skateboard or scooter involved in such violation may be impounded by the police department for a period not to exceed 30 days unless it is considered evidence. 
(1)  The owner of any bicycle, skateboard or scooter that have been impounded may request a hearing on the merits of the impoundment before the chief of police or his designee. 
(2)  A hearing will be conducted within two days following a request, weekends and holidays excluded. Emergency conditions may also result in the hearing date being extended. 
(3)  The person holding the hearing may uphold, overturn or modify the term of impoundment. 
(4)  Following the hearing, the chief of police or his designee shall render a decision and notify the owner by letter within two days unless the item has been returned to the owner. 
(c)  A civil forfeiture may be imposed for violating this article as follows: 
(1)  $15.00 for a first offense. 
(2)  $25.00 for a second offense. 
(3)  $35.00 for a third offense. 
(4)  $50.00 for any subsequent offenses. 
(d)  A civil forfeiture of up to $50.00 may be imposed against any person who neglects to pick up a bicycle, skateboard or scooter after 14 days from the time he is eligible for the item's return. 
(Prior Code,  14.9.5; Ord. No. 2003-16, 8-20-2003) 
Sec. 30-106. - Bicycle registration; non-transferability. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or operate any bicycle upon any way or upon any sidewalk within the town without first having registered the same with the police department. This shall not apply to nonresidents of the town. Any owner or person having custody and control of any bicycle must attach or affix a designated registration sticker to the said bicycle and display it in a conspicuous place. Registration fees and periods of registration shall be established by the chief of police. 
(b)  In order to be registered, a bicycle shall: 
(1)  Be in good, safe mechanical condition; 
(2)  Be equipped with an audible signaling device and adequate brakes; and 
(3)  Have a distinctive identification marker or serial number. 
(Prior Code,  14.9.2; Ord. No. 2003-16, 8-20-2003) 
Sec. 30-107. - Operation of bicycles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or operate any bicycle upon any way or upon any sidewalk within the town one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise without a visible light and without adequate reflective equipment or adequate reflective gear. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or operate any bicycle upon any way or sidewalk within the town and carry any passengers unless the said bicycle is equipped with a seat for said passenger. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or operate any bicycle upon any way or sidewalk within the town unless said bicycle or operator is equipped with an audible signaling device and adequate brakes. The bicycle must be in good and safe mechanical condition and possess a distinctive identification number or serial number. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or operate any bicycle upon any way or sidewalk within the town in violation of all applicable and pertinent chapters of state law. 
(Prior Code,  14.9.3; Ord. No. 2003-16, 8-20-2003) 
Sec. 30-108. - Operation of skateboards and scooters. 
(a)  The operation of skateboards and scooters shall be permitted within the town except on sidewalks within the downtown vicinity (on Main Street from the intersection of Elm Street to the intersection of Beech Street Extension). 
(b)  All skateboards and scooters shall be ridden or operated with due care with regard for rules governing pedestrian traffic and safety. 
(c)  The operation of skateboards and scooters shall not be permitted to interfere with the normal flow of vehicular traffic. 
(d)  Any person riding or operating a skateboard or scooter one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise shall be required to have reflective material visible in order not to impose a hazard to the motoring public. 
(Prior Code,  14.9.4; Ord. No. 2003-16, 8-20-2003) 
CHAPTER 31 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Exh. A of Ord. No. 2014/2015-01, adopted Dec. 17, 2014, added provisions to the Code, but did not specify manner of inclusion. Therefore, at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been included as  31-21-31-31, 31-41, 31-51-31-53. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 31-1-31-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RULES AND REGULATIONS 

Sec. 31-21. - Water use and payment. 
(a)  The following regulations shall be considered a part of the contract with every person who uses water, and every such person taking water shall be considered to express the assent to be bound thereby. 
(b)  In case of violation by a customer of any regulation established by the Newmarket Town Council, or on non-payment of rates or accounts due, his supply shall be cut off pursuant to the procedure set forth in these regulations. The water will not be turned on again until all cause and complaints are removed and dues paid. 
(Ord. No. 2014/2015-01, Exh.(Ch. 2,  1), 12-17-2014) 
Sec. 31-22. - Water services. 
(a)  A separate service and connection to the water distribution main shall be required for any new property which is to be used as a dwelling or a place of business. 
(b)  No water permit shall be issued for additional units to any building which does not have its own individual water service from curb to meter, 
(c)  No customer shall install or use water consumption apparatus which will affect the pressure or operation conditions so as to interfere with the service of another customer. 
(d)  Every free-standing building used for residential purposes requiring water shall have a separate water service line from the curb stop to the meter and shall have a separate curb stop located outside the building and accessible to the water division at all times. No building shall be fed water through another building unless both buildings shall be owned by the same party and the outbuilding being serviced contains no residential units. 
(e)  Unless approved by the superintendent of the water division, in a building containing more than one residential or commercial unit, and where each of these units may have a different owner, every unit shall have its own water meter, its own water service line from the curb to the meter and its own curb stop located outside the building and accessible by the water division at all times. 
(Ord. No. 2014/2015-01, Exh.(Ch. 2,  2), 12-17-2014) 
Sec. 31-23. - Ownership of services. 
    All new service pipe and fittings will be laid from the main to the meter at the water-takers expenses. Said service piping will be inspected by the superintendent of water or his authorized representative before any back filling is accomplished. That portion of the water service between the curb stop and the meter will be maintained by the user, except the meter which is installed and owned by the water division. Replacement of the water service from the main to the curb shall be the responsibility of the water division. 
(Ord. No. 2014/2015-01, Exh.(Ch. 2,  3), 12-17-2014) 
Sec. 31-24. - Fire protection devices and fountain use. 
(a)  Private fire protection service request shall be submitted to the public works department, or his designees, for approval and must be accompanied by a plan of the proposing piping system, together with a statement telling for what other purposes the system might be used. 
(b)  The water division does not promise to furnish proper quantities of water through any public or private fire service, nor does it promise to undertake any activity relative to that service. 
(Ord. No. 2014/2015-01, Exh.(Ch. 2,  5), 12-17-2014) 
Sec. 31-25. - Water meters. 
(a)  When the customer fails or neglects to furnish a suitable location for a meter inside the building, or when, for other reasons, it is necessary or expedient to locate the meter in an underground box or vault, the customer will bear the expense of all costs associated with the installation of said meter. 
(b)  For services up to 3/4 in size, meter repairs or replacements necessitated by ordinary wear will be paid for by the water division. Those repairs necessitated by freezing, hot water, willful damage, or fault of the customer will be charged by the customer. 
(c)  Access to meters. The customer, upon connection of service, shall be deemed to have granted permission for the reading, inspection, and installation of meters, including the installation of remote readers for meters. 
(d)  When water passing through a single meter is used to serve more than one dwelling, the owner of the premises of which the meter is located, irrespective of under leases or individual consumers, shall be held to pay the full rate or any balance of the rate thereof for the entire amount of water passing through said meter (called the "master meter") per the schedule below; 
(1)  Any individual dwelling meter shall first be read, recorded and billed to the dwelling; and paid for by the dwelling. 
(2)  Any master meter shall be read, recorded and compared to the sum of the individual dwelling meters. Any positive discrepancy between the individual meter and master meter shall be billed and paid for by the premise owner; as indicated above. 
(e)  Seasonal meters. Meters will be removed, stored and reinstalled when the customer requires such because of the nature of the business or the likelihood of freezing. Such installations will be subject to normal turn-on/turn-off fees. 
(f)  Deduct meters are only authorized for use in monitoring outside water usage for purposes of establishing credits on sewer bills. 
(1)  Deduct meters shall be of a standard type as specified by the water department. 
(2)  Deduct meters are to be installed with a backflow preventer and isolation valves. The customer shall be responsible for the purchase, maintenance and installation by a licensed plumber. 
(3)  As a courtesy, the deduct meters will be read at the same time as the domestic water meters. The deduct meter readings will be relayed to the finance office with the domestic water meter readings. 
(Ord. No. 2014/2015-01, Exh.(Ch. 2,  6), 12-17-2014) 
Sec. 31-26. - Billing and payment. 
(a)  Customers shall be charged for services and water consumption in accordance with the prevailing rates established by the town council and published in the Town of Newmarket Fee and Charges Schedule. 
(b)  The town shall assess a delinquency charge sufficient to cover the cost of collecting the delinquent bill, which is in arrears for one full quarter or more. In no event shall the town assess a charge less than the amount shown in the fee and charges schedule. 
(c)  The town shall accept partial payments of no less than one-third of unpaid arrears as a precondition to restoring discontinued services. In such event, the delinquent customer shall satisfy the entire balance within ten working days. In the event, the delinquent customer does not satisfy the entire balance within working days the town may immediately discontinue service. 
(Ord. No. 2014/2015-01, Exh.(Ch. 2,  7), 12-17-2014) 
Sec. 31-27. - Procedures in non-payment. 
(a)  Liens. Under the provision of New Hampshire RSA 38:22 (c), all charges for water services shall constitute a lien in favor of the Town of Newmarket upon the real estate where the services were furnished and the lien shall continue for 18 months date of the last paid bill, unless the town records in the Rockingham County Registry of Deeds a notice of lien, in which case the lien shall continue for six years from the date of the last unpaid bill. The lien may be enforced in a suit by the town against the owner of such real estate. In such a suit, the town shall have the right to a judgment per year charges, entered at a rate of 12 percent, and subject to change, from the date of the last unpaid bill to date of judgment, and costs. The records in the water and sewer division shall be sufficient notice to maintain suit upon the lien against subsequent purchases or attaching creditors or real estate. 
(b)  The execution and recording of a lien pursuant to this section shall in addition to, and shall not be exclusive of, other remedies available to the town at law or equity, including but not limited to, discontinuation of service pursuant to section 31-28. The town shall have the sole discretion to determine which procedure to utilize in the event that an owner or customer fails to pay claims for service or charges. 
(Ord. No. 2014/2015-01, Exh.(Ch. 2,  8), 12-17-2014) 
Sec. 31-28. - Violation and enforcement. 
(a)  Any violations of the provisions of these rules and regulations, or failure on the part of any customer utilizing the water to promptly and pay all claims for service or other charges of the water division, shall be sufficient cause for shutting off the water supply of such customer and such supply shall not be turned on again until all such cause of complaint have been removed, including any additional work costs incurred for turning on and off the water. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any regulation to the contrary, the town shall not discontinue service without notice to a customer if any part of the service provided benefits one or more parties known to the town to be a residential tenant. In such instance, the town shall provide notice compliant with RSA 38:31, as amended, unless (1) the discontinuance of service is ordered by the chief of police, fire chief, building inspector, or other public health officer and (2) the discontinuance of service is necessary to avoid damage or injury to life or property. 
The discontinuation of service pursuant to this section shall be in addition to, and shall not be exclusive of, other remedies available to the town at law or equity, including but not limited to, the execution and recording of a lien pursuant to section 31-27 for failure to pay all claims for service or other changes. The town shall have the sole discretion to determine which procedure to utilize in the event of a violation of these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2014/2015-01, Exh.(Ch. 2,  9), 12-17-2014) 
Sec. 31-29. - Damage and liability. 
(a)  Notice of shutoff will be given when practicable, however, nothing in this rule shall be construed as requiring the water division to provide such notice. 
(b)  All customers having direct pressure hot water tanks or appliances must place proper automatic vacuum and relief valves in the pipe system to prevent any damage to such tanks or appliances in the event that the town shuts off water to the street main(s) or service pipe(s). Water service will be provided to such direct pressure installations only at the customers risk and in no case shall the water division be liable for any damage occasioned thereby. 
(Ord. No. 2014/2015-01, Exh.(Ch. 2,  10), 12-17-2014) 
Sec. 31-30. - Repeal of inconsistent charter. 
    All provisions, rules, regulations and rates inconsistent herein, are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 2014/2015-01, Exh.(Ch. 2,  14), 12-17-2014) 
Sec. 31-31. - Additions and amendments. 
    The foregoing rules and regulations are subject to amendment at a duly convened public meeting of the town council in accordance with RSA chapter 91-A. 
(Ord. No. 2014/2015-01, Exh.(Ch. 2,  15), 12-17-2014) 
Secs. 31-32-31-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PROVISIONS FOR MAIN PIPE EXTENSION 

Sec. 31-41. - Review and approval process for developers and contractors. 
(a)  Plans must be submitted to the public works department a minimum of 30 days prior to the date of approval. 
(1)  Plans shall be drafted on 24" X 34" plan and profile sheets with a horizontal scale of 1" = 20" or 1" = 40'. Detail sheets need not be on plan - profile sheets. 
(2)  Specifications shall be type written on standard 8 1/2" x 11" sheets. 
(b)  Water mains in new subdivisions to be served by the Town of Newmarket shall be installed by the developer or contractor at his expense according to specifications established by the Town of Newmarket and the supervision of the water division. The developer, contractor, or other party will be responsible for defects in materials and workmanship in any water system for one year after the acceptance of that water system improvements by the Town of Newmarket. 
(c)  The developer or contractor shall, as a condition of any approval, save and hold the town harmless against any and all claims arising out of the extension or construction of the water main. 
(d)  Upon completion of the water system or parts thereof, the developers or contractors shall obtain a written certification from the superintendent of the water division that said system has been constructed strictly to these regulations. Said certification shall be required prior to the acceptance of said water system, or parts thereof, by the Town of Newmarket. A letter of approval signed by the public works director, delivered to the developer, contractor or other party, shall be sufficient evidence that the Town of Newmarket has in fact accepted the water system or parts thereof. 
(e)  Whenever a developer, contractor or other party is found in violation of any of these regulations, the superintendent of the water division may cause any and all installation or construction activity to cease until such violations have ceased and have been corrected. Any decision to stop the installation of a water system, or parts thereof, by the superintendent of the water division may be appealed to the town administrator in writing. 
(f)  If a developer or contractor or other party is found to be in violation of the provisions of article IV of those regulations, the superintendent of the water division may appoint a representative to inspect the work on a full-time basis. The salary or salaries paid for said representative(s) shall be borne by the developer or contractor, until such time as the superintendent is reasonably satisfied that the contractor, developer, or other party shall follow these regulations. Such decisions may be appealed to the town administrator pursuant to section 31-41(d) of these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2014/2015-01, Exh.(Ch. 3,  2), 12-17-2014) 
Secs. 31-42-31-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - REQUIREMENTS FOR WATER MAIN AND SERVICES 

Sec. 31-51. - Construction materials. 
(a)  Water mains. Pipe shall be a minimum of inches in diameter or as determined by the water division, and shall conform to ANSI Standards for ductile iron pipe, in all categories, including but not limited to, lining, protective coatings and laying length. The minimum pipe thickness shall be class 52. 
(1)  Ductile iron pipe shall have push-on joints with rubber gaskets, except where pipe is to be joined with special fittings or valves, in which case pipe shall be furnished with mechanical joints. 
(2)  Marking pipe. Each ductile iron pipe shall have conspicuously painted on the exterior the pressure, class, and weight of the pipe. 
(3)  Linings and coatings. The outside surface of all pipes shall be factory coated with bituminous, coating of either coal tar or asphalt base approximately one millimeter thick. The inside surface of all pipe shall be a double cement mortar lining and bituminous seal coat in strict accordance with ANSI Standard A2.4/AWWA C104-LR for "cement-mortar lining for cast-iron pipe with fittings for water". 
(4)  Manufacturer's affidavit of factory inspection and testing. Upon request, the developer shall supply a sworn affidavit of compliance that all hydrostatic and physical properties tests have been made and that the results of the same comply with the American Standard's Association (ASA) requirements. 
(5)  Developers responsibility for material. The developer is responsible for all materials during all stages of development, including but not limited to, the procurement of materials, handling and storage of said materials, and installation. The interior of the pipe shall be kept free of dirt and foreign matter at all times. The developer shall exercise due care over said material, and the developer shall not use materials that have been dropped, bumped, or whose structural integrity or effectiveness has otherwise been called into question due to damage. Detrimental abrasions to coatings shall be repaired by the contractor or be cause for pipe replacement. 
(6)  Ductile iron pipe fittings. Fittings for ductile iron water pipe shall be ductile or cast iron and meet the requirements of AWWA C110. The outside surface of all fittings shall be coated by hot coal tar dip method before lining. Inside cement lining shall be in accordance with AWWA C104. The minimum pressure rating for all fittings shall be 250 pounds per square inch (psi) unless a higher pressure class is required for the specific installation. Unless otherwise required for joint restraint, joints on fittings shall be mechanical in accordance to AWWA C111. 
(b)  Gate Valves. Gate valves should be iron body bronze mounted, resilient seat, mechanical joint, with stainless steel nuts and bolts for underground use, wrench operated, non-rising stem, and "O-ring" seal in accordance with AWWA C509. All valves shall be "OPEN LEFT", and shall have the makers' initials, pressure rating, and year of manufacturer cast on the body. Valves 12 inches and smaller shall be suitable and designed by the manufacturer for water working pressure of 200 psi and valves larger than 12 inches shall have a working pressure of 150 psi. Gate valves shall have a two inch square nut for wrench operation and the operating nut shall have an arrow cast in metal indicating the direction of opening. Gate valves shall be Mueller 2360 series or approved equal. 
(c)  Valve boxes. Valve boxes shall be heavy pattern cast or ductile iron, cast in two or three telescoping sections of sliding construction and at such lengths as will provide, without full extension, the required cover. The lower section shall be 5 1/4" inch inside diameter and shall be valve and domed at the bottom to fit over the valve nut. The upper section shall fit over the lower section, unless otherwise infeasible. Covers shall: 
(1)  Be at least six inches in diameter; 
(2)  Fit flush with the top surface; 
(3)  Shall be slotted for easy removal; and 
(4)  Have the words "water" and "open" and a direction arrow plainly cast in relief on the top surface. 
Valve boxes shall be free of defects in material and workmanship, and shall be coated with coal tar pitch enamel or other approved coatings. 
(d)  Hydrants. 
(1)  All hydrants shall be post fire hydrants shall have a minimum five and one-half inch opening, six inch hub inlet, two two-and-one-half inch hoses, and one four-and-one-half inch pumper nozzles with National Standard Threads. 
(2)  The opening nut shall open by turning to the LEFT. Said nut shall be five sided, one-and-one-half point to flat. 
(3)  Hydrant shall conform to the latest revision of AWWA Standard for Fire Hydrants for Ordinary Water Works Service, serial designation C502-LR. Hydrants shall be fitted with stainless steel nuts and bolts. Hydrants shall be Mueller Super Centurion 250 or approved equal. 
(4)  In areas of installation where the ground water table is higher than that of dry barrel hydrant drains, the drains shall be plugged. Information pertaining to the location of plugged hydrants shall be sent to the Newmarket Fire Department. 
(e)  Corporate stops. Corporation stops shall be three-quarters of an inch, unless otherwise required, and shall be ball type compression. INLET: AWWA taper CC thread; OUTLET: Conductive compression connection for copper tubing sizing (C.T.S) outside diameter (O.D.) Corporation stops shall be Mueller 300 series, Ford F Series or approved equal. 
(f)  Copper water tube. Copper water tube shall be three-quarters (3/4) of an inch, unless otherwise required, and shall be soft temper, type "K," and conform to ASTM B-88. No splices will be allowed from the corporation stop to the curb box stop. 
(g)  Curb stops. Curb stops shall be three-quarters of an inch, unless otherwise required, and shall be ball type compression with conductive compression connections for copper tubing sizing (C.T.S) and outside diameter (O.D.) on both ends. Curb stops shall be Mueller 300 series, Ford Z series or approved equal. 
(h)  Curb boxes. Curb boxes shall conform to the specification for valve boxes. Curb stops need not conform to the specifications for valve boxes when for curb stops two inches and smaller, which in such case shall have a one-piece cast or ductile iron arch base, a steel pipe extension upper section, cast iron lid, and thread bronze plug with pentagon hex nut (rope thread). A stationary five-eights inch minimum diameter by 24 to 30 inches minimum stainless steel long rod shall be installed at the curb box. Curb boxes shall be set plumb and flush with final grade. In addition, no obstruction shall be placed to obstruct use of shut-off valve wrench within a four foot circumference from the center of the curb box. 
(i)  Backfill. 
(1)  Common fill mineral soil substantially free from organic materials, loam, wood, trash, and other objectionable materials which may be compressible or which cannot be properly compacted. Common fill should contain no stones larger than 6 inches in diameter. Common fill shall have properties such that it can be readily spread and compacted. Snow, ice, and frozen material shall not be permitted. 
(2)  Screened gravel shall be well graded in size from one-quarter inch to three-quarter inch and shall consist of clean, hard, and durable particles or fragments. Screen gravel shall be free from dirt, vegetable, or other objectionable matter, and shall not be comprised of an excess of soft, thin elongated, laminated, or disintegrated pieces. The grading should conform to the following requirements: 
Square Opening 1-inch 3/4-inch 3/8 -inch No. 4 No. 8 % Passing by Weight 100 96-100 20-55 0-10 0-5  
(3)  Granular fill consist of hard, durable stone and course sand, free from frost, frozen lumps loam and clay, well graded, and containing no stones having and dimension greater than one inch. The grading of the sizes and material shall be such that the gravel may be thoroughly consolidated. The grading shall conform to the following requirements: 
Square Opening 3/4-inch No. 4 No. 40 No. 200 % Passing by Weight 100 96-100 20-55 0-10  
(j)  Pavement. Provide all materials in accordance with the applicable sections of the latest edition of the Standard Specification for Highways and Bridges of the New Hampshire Department of Transportation (NHDOT). 
(Ord. No. 2014/2015-01, Exh.(Ch. 4,  2), 12-17-2014) 
Sec. 31-52. - Construction methods. 
(a)  Trench excavation. the contractor shall be responsible to excavate trench/trenches in a manner consistent with all safety requirements provided by State, federal, and local law and regulations for the soil types involved. The contractor is required to do all dewatering of the trench which may be necessary to insure the trench bottom is firm and dry. If, in the opinion of the water division, unsatisfactory soil conditions exist at the required trench grade, the contractor may be required to excavate below normal trench grade until suitable foundation material is encountered. The excavation shall then be backfilled with screened gravel in six in layers. Each layer shall be properly tamped and compacted until normal trench grade is obtained. The contractor shall make such additional excavations as may be necessary to provide for proper placement of concrete thrust blocks, valves, hydrants, services and other appurtenances as shown on plans or as required by the water division. 
(b)  Cover. All water main trenches shall be such that a minimum cover of five to six feet is provided over the pipe, where possible, except at gate valves whereupon a minimum of three feet of cover shall be provided at the top of the valve bonnet. The maximum depth of cover shall be seven feet unless otherwise approved by the Water Division. 
(c)  Bedding the pipe and fittings. All pipe and fittings shall be placed on a layer of bedding material consisting of compacted screened gravel or granular fill. The depth of bedding shall be six inches minimum or equal to one half the diameter of the pipe, whichever is greater. Any voids under the pipe shall be filled and thoroughly tamped. 
(d)  Laying the pipe and fittings. The pipe shall be placed in the trench in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations or by an approved method in such a manner so as to insure that the pipe is not damaged. All pipes shall be thoroughly sound, dry and clean before laying, and the utmost care shall be taken to insure that the pipes condition are not altered when placed on the bed. Water tight plugs shall be installed once the pipes are in place to keep out water and dirt. All work associated with laying the pipes shall conform to AWWA Standard Specification C600 wherever said specifications are applicable and not in conflict with the provisions contained in these regulations. When the pipe is in place, screened gravel or granular fill, whichever is suitable under the circumstances, shall be placed in the trench and thoroughly compacted in six inch lifts to 12 inches above the top of the pipe. 
(1)  Valves. Gate valves shall be installed to permit isolation of sections of the water mains for the purposes of flushing and to facilitate future repairs on the water mains. The location of gate valves shall be approved by the water division. Valves shall be installed as close as possible to plumb and in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations. Valve boxes shall be installed at every valve location. Valve boxes shall be adjusted to the proper finish grade and shall be set plumb and centered over the operating nut of the valve. After installation is completed, all valves shall be operated and then left in the closed position. Valves and tee's shall be roded together. 
(2)  Tapping sleeves and valves. Tapping sleeves and valves shall be installed with the outlet flange set vertically and the sleeve squarely centered on the main. Concrete or granite blocking shall be placed beneath the sleeve and valve to provide support. Concrete thrust blocking shall be placed behind and under the sleeve and valve after the tap is completed. The valve shall be flushed after completion of the taps to ensure that the valve seat is clean. Bituminous coating shall be applied to the nuts and bolts holding the sleeve together. 
(3)  Hydrants. Hydrants will be installed along all mains at a maximum separation of one thousand (1,000') feet. Notwithstanding this provision, hydrants will be installed no further than six-hundred (600) feet from any structure. The Town of Newmarket Fire Department may, in its discretion, require shorter distances based on required fire flow. The hydrant shall be set plumb and at the proper elevation with respect to the final finished grade. The breakaway flange shall be set two inches above finish grade. The hydrant base shall be set on fine material. The hydrant branch valve shall be adequately anchored together by mechanical means (anchor tee or threaded rod) and by concrete thrust blocks. The final location of hydrants shall be approved by the water division. Prior to any hydrant being tested under pressure, all hydrants, laterals, and mains shall be flushed to remove dirt, rocks, and foreign matter. Each nozzle and pumper outlet shall be at least 18 inches above grade on the installed hydrant. All steamer connection shall face the travel way. Each hydrant shall be provided with an approved gate valve located three feet from the hydrant, but not located within the travel way. The hydrant and tee shall be roded together. Hydrants shall be painted to meet the Newmarket Water Division requirements for color. 
(e)  Thrust restraint. Concrete thrust blocks and joint restraints shall be installed at all bends, fittings, dead ends and hydrants as directed by the Water Division. Thrust blocks shall be pre-cast. Trench formed thrust blocks will not be acceptable. The bearing area of the thrust blocks shall be determined for each installation based on soil type and system design pressure. In the event that local conditions prohibit the use of thrust blocks, the contractor shall furnish and install additional mechanical thrust resisting devices, upon the approval of such devices by the water division. 
(f)  Service connections. Service shall be constructed in accordance with the most recent revision of the BOCA, CABO, and International Plumbing Codes. Service pipe connections will be made only from the street where is the legal address of the premises served is located. 
(1)  Corporation stops. The contractor shall furnish and install all corporation stops at locations as directed by the water division. A tapping machine shall be used which will permit tapping of water mains under pressure. The tapping machine shall be rigidly fastened to the pipe and the tap shall be made in the upper one-half of the pipe. The length of travel of the tap shall be so established that when the stop is inserted and tightened with a 14 inch wrench, not more than one to three threads will be exposed on the outside. Taps shall be at least 18 inches apart at a minimum. 
(2)  Copper tubing. The contractor shall furnish and install copper tubing at locations as directed by the water division. Excavation for services shall be to a minimum depth of five feet, and the contractor shall exercise special care to insure that the bottom is free from sharp rocks or ledge outcroppings. In placing the service in the trench, the contractor shall ensure that the copper tubing has no kinks or sharp bends and that the screened gravel (or granular fill) is placed to the depth of six inches over. The contractor shall also ensure that the area around the service is free from large or sharp stones which may come in contact with the service. 
(3)  Temporary service connection. Temporary service connections shall be at the customer's expense and shall include, but shall not be limited to, connections to buildings or trailers mounted on foundations, gardens, or any other connections made for a temporary use. 
(Ord. No. 2014/2015-01, Exh.(Ch. 4,  3), 12-17-2014) 
Sec. 31-53. - Electrical power and telephone lines. 
(a)  Underground electric and telephone lines, cables, or conduit shall not be installed in the same trench as the water main. 
(b)  Wherever possible, the electric and telephone lines shall be installed on the opposite side of the street from the water main. However, if it is necessary to install underground power and telephone lines on the same side of the street as the water main, the approval of the superintendent of the water division shall be required. 
(c)  Wherever the electric or telephone lines must cross either mains or service branches, the installation shall be in conduit encased in concrete. The concrete shall extend laterally for a minimum distance of five feet from each side of the water installation. 
(d)  If the lines are laid parallel to mains or service branches, including those between the street shut-off and the house service, there must be a minimum of six (6) feet of lateral separation. 
(e)  There shall be no installation of any electric or telephone line within ten (10) feet of a hydrant or house service street shut-off. 
(1)  Warning Tape. All water, electric, cable, and telephone lines must be marked with underground warning tape located a minimum of one foot to six inches above the utility or as otherwise required by state or federal law or regulation. 
Private Fire Protection. There shall be a separate pipe, gated on Municipal property, for private fire protection. In no case shall the fire service pipe be used for anything other than fire protection. 
(Ord. No. 2014/2015-01, Exh.(Ch. 4,  4), 12-17-2014)
